question: Question 1 Consider a system represented by the block diagram shown below. Which of the following signal flow graphs represent(s) this system? Choose the correct option(s).
solution:
Using mason's gain formula, given block diagram Overall T.F [latex]=\frac{Y(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{G_{1}+G_{2}}{1+G_{1}}[/latex] verify using options
[latex]\frac{\mathrm{Y}(\mathrm{s})}{\mathrm{R}(\mathrm{s})}=\frac{\mathrm{G}_{1}+\mathrm{G}_{2}}{1+\mathrm{G}_{1}+\mathrm{G}_{2}} \rightarrow[/latex] wrong [latex]\frac{\mathrm{Y}(\mathrm{s})}{\mathrm{R}(\mathrm{s})}=\frac{\mathrm{G}_{1}+\mathrm{G}_{2}}{1+\mathrm{G}_{1}} \rightarrow[/latex] correct [latex]\frac{\mathrm{Y}(\mathrm{s})}{\mathrm{R}(\mathrm{s})}=\frac{\mathrm{G}_{1}+\mathrm{G}_{2}}{1-\mathrm{G}_{1}-\mathrm{G}_{2}} \rightarrow[/latex] wrong [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{G_{1}+G_{2}}{1+G_{1}+G_{2}} \rightarrow[/latex] wrong

question: Question 2 Consider a system where [latex]{x}_{1}({t}), {x}_{2}({t})[/latex], and [latex]{x}_{3}({t})[/latex] are three internal state signals and [latex]u(t)[/latex] is the input signal. The differential equations governing the system are given by [latex]\frac{d}{d t}\left[\begin{array}{l}x_{1}(t) \\ x_{2}(t) \\ x_{3}(t)\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}x_{1}(t) \\ x_{2}(t) \\ x_{3}(t)\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 1 \\ 1\end{array}\right] u(t)[/latex]. Which of the following statements is/are TRUE?
solution:
Here given "A" matrix is in the diagonal canonical form [D.C.F] hence T.F [latex]=\frac{\mathrm{k}_{1}}{(\mathrm{~s}-2)}+\frac{\mathrm{k}_{2}}{(\mathrm{~s}+2)}+\frac{\mathrm{k}_{3}}{\mathrm{~s}}[/latex]

Here poles [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{s}=-2,+2,0[/latex] Here one pole is in the right half of s-plane so at least one of the signals [latex]{x}_{1}({t}), {x}_{2}({t})[/latex] and [latex]{x}_{3}({t})[/latex] are unbounded.

options.A: The signals [latex]x_{1}(t), x_{2}(t)[/latex], and [latex]x_{3}(t)[/latex] are bounded for all bounded inputs
options.B: There exists a bounded input such that at least one of the signals [latex]x_{1}(t), x_{2}(t)[/latex], and [latex]x_{3}(t)[/latex] is unbounded
options.C: There exists a bounded input such that the signals [latex]x_{1}(t), x_{2}(t)[/latex], and [latex]x_{3}(t)[/latex] are unbounded
options.D: The signals [latex]x_{1}(t), x_{2}(t)[/latex], and [latex]x_{3}(t)[/latex] are unbounded for all bounded inputs

question: Question 3 Consider the polynomial [latex]p(s)=s^{5}+7 s^{4}+3 s^{3}-33 s^{2}+2 s-40[/latex]. Let [latex](L,I,R)[/latex] be defined as follows. [latex]L[/latex] is the number of roots of [latex]p(s)[/latex] with negative real parts. [latex]I[/latex] is the number of roots of [latex]\mathrm{p}(\mathrm{s})[/latex] that are purely imaginary. [latex]R[/latex] is the number of roots of [latex]p(s)[/latex] with positive real parts. Which one of the following options is correct?
solution:
Given [latex]p(s)=s^{5}+7 s^{4}+3 s^{3}-33 s^{2}+2 s-40[/latex] [latex]
\begin{array}{l|lrl}
s^{5} & 1 & 3 & 2 \\
s^{4} & 7 & -33 & -40 \\
s^{3} & \frac{54}{7} & \frac{54}{7} & 0 \\
s^{2} & -40 & -40 & 0 \\
s^{1} & 0(-80) & 0 & 0 \\
s^{0} & -40 &  &  \\
\end{array}
[/latex] Auxiliary equation [A.E] [latex]-40 \mathrm{~s}^{2}-40=0[/latex] A.E [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{s}^{2}+1=0 \Rightarrow \mathrm{~s}^{2}=-1 \Rightarrow \mathrm{~s}= \pm 1 \mathrm{j}[/latex] So number of imaginary roots [latex][\mathrm{I}]=2[/latex] In the RH tabular, number of sign changes in the first column [latex]=1[/latex], hence number of poles in the right half of s-plane (or) roots with positive real parts [latex][R]=1[/latex], number of poles in the left half of s-plane [latex][\mathrm{L}]=5-2-1=2[/latex]

question: Question 4 Let [latex]\mathrm{G}(\mathrm{s})=\frac{1}{10 \mathrm{~s}^{2}}[/latex] be the transfer function of a secondorder system. A controller M(s) is connected to the system [latex]\mathrm{G}(\mathrm{s})[/latex] in the configuration shown below. Consider the following statements. (i) There exists no controller of the form [latex]M(s)=\frac{K_{I}}{s}[/latex], where [latex]K_{I}[/latex] is a positive real number, such that the closed loop system is stable. (ii) There exists at least one controller of the form [latex]\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{s})=\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{P}}+\mathrm{s} \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{D}}[/latex], where [latex]\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{P}}[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{D}}[/latex] are positive real numbers, such that the closed loop system is stable. Which one of the following options is correct?
solution: Statement (i): Given integral controller, integral controller adds pole at origin result system becomes unstable hence for closed loop system stability no integral controller, so statement (i) is true. Statement (ii): Given PD controller, which adds zero result system becomes stable, hence statement (ii) is also true.

question: Question 5 Consider the unity-negative-feedback system shown in Figure (i) below, where gain  [latex]K \geq 0[/latex]. The root locus of this system is shown in Figure (ii) below. For what value(s) of  [latex]K[/latex] will the system in Figure (i) have a pole at  [latex]-1+ji[/latex]?
solution: We are given the root locus plot in Figure (ii), and we are to determine whether a closed-loop pole lies at the complex location [latex] -1 + j1 [/latex] for any [latex] K \geq 0 [/latex]. From control theory, the root locus shows the trajectory of the closed-loop poles as [latex] K [/latex] varies from [latex] 0 [/latex] to [latex] \infty [/latex]. We inspect the root locus diagram in Figure (ii): The root locus branches are symmetric about the real axis. The point [latex] -1 + j1 [/latex] lies outside the plotted root locus path. It is not marked or touched by any of the root locus branches. Hence, the closed-loop poles never pass through the point [latex] -1 + j1 [/latex] for any positive value of [latex] K [/latex].

question: Question 6 The Nyquist plot of a system is given in the figure. Let [latex] \omega_P, \omega_Q, \omega_R [/latex] and [latex] \omega_S [/latex] be the positive frequencies at the points [latex]P, Q, R,[/latex] and [latex]S,[/latex] respectively. Which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution:
From the Nyquist plot: The gain crossover frequency is the frequency at which the Nyquist plot crosses the unit circle, i.e., the magnitude of the open-loop transfer function [latex] |G(j\omega)H(j\omega)| = 1 [/latex]. The phase crossover frequency is the frequency at which the phase is [latex] -180^\circ [/latex], i.e., the Nyquist plot crosses the negative real axis. From the diagram: Point S lies on the unit circle, so [latex] \omega_S [/latex] is the gain crossover frequency. Point P lies on the negative real axis, hence [latex] \omega_P [/latex] is the phase crossover frequency. Therefore, the correct statement is:
[latex] \omega_S [/latex] is the gain crossover frequency and [latex] \omega_P [/latex] is the phase crossover frequency.

options.A: [latex] \omega_S [/latex] is the gain crossover frequency and [latex] \omega_P [/latex] is the phase crossover frequency
options.B: [latex] \omega_Q [/latex] is the gain crossover frequency and [latex] \omega_S [/latex] is the phase crossover frequency
options.C: [latex] \omega_R [/latex] is the gain crossover frequency and [latex] \omega_S [/latex] is the phase crossover frequency
options.D: [latex] \omega_S [/latex] is the gain crossover frequency and [latex] \omega_Q [/latex] is the phase crossover frequency

question: Question 8 A satellite attitude control system, as shown below, has a plant with transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{s^{2}}[/latex] cascaded with a compensator [latex]C(s)=\frac{K(s+\alpha)}{s+4}[/latex], where [latex]K[/latex] and [latex]\alpha[/latex] are positive real constants. In order for the closed-loop system to have poles at [latex]-1 \pm j \sqrt{3}[/latex], the value of [latex]\alpha[/latex] must be ____
solution:
[latex]
G(S) C(s)=\frac{1}{S^{2}} \frac{k(S+\alpha)}{(S+4)}
[/latex] Characteristic equation is [latex]
S^{3}+4 S^{2}+k S+\alpha=0
[/latex] Poles of the system present at [latex]=-1 \pm j \sqrt{3}[/latex] Characteristic equation is [latex]
\begin{aligned}
&(S+a)\left[(S+1)^{2}+3\right]=0 \\
&(S+a)\left(S^{2}+2 S+4\right)=0 \\
& S^{3}+(2+a) S^{2}+(4+2 a) S+4 a=0
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Compare equation (I) and (II) [latex]
\begin{aligned}
2+a & =4 \\
a & =2 \\
4+2 a & =k \\
k & =8 \\
k \alpha & =4 a \\
\alpha & =\frac{8}{8}=1 \\
\alpha & =1
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question:
Question 9 Consider a unity negative feedback control system with forward path gain [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{(s+1)(s+2)(s+3)}[/latex] as shown.
The impulse response of the closed-loop system decays faster than [latex]e^{-t}[/latex] if ______
solution:
Given, [latex]
G(s)=\frac{K}{(S+1)(S+2)(S+3)}
[/latex] Impulse response of system is [latex]
Y(S)=\frac{K}{(S+1)(S+2)(S+3)+K}
[/latex] Given: At impulse response of closed loop system decay faster than [latex]e^{-t}[/latex] Hence, put [latex]s=s-1[/latex], [latex]\therefore[/latex] The new characteristic equation is, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& (s-1+1)(s-1+2)(s-1+3)+K=0 \\
& s(s+1)(s+2)+K=0 \\
& s^{3}+3 s^{2}+2 s+K=0
\end{aligned}
[/latex] By [latex]\mathrm{RH}[/latex] criterion, [latex]
\begin{array}{c|cc}
s^{3} & 1 & 2 \\
s^{2} & 3 & K \\
s^{1} & \frac{6-K}{3} & \\
s^{0} & K &
\end{array}
[/latex] [latex]
\therefore K \gt 0 ; \quad \frac{6-K}{3} \gt 0 \Rightarrow K \lt 6
[/latex] [latex]
\therefore \quad 0 \lt K \lt 6
[/latex] Hence, option satisfies above range of [latex]K[/latex].

question: Question 10 In the feedback control system shown in the figure below [latex]G(s)=\frac{6}{s(s+1)(s+2)}[/latex]. [latex]R(s), Y(s)[/latex], and [latex]E(s)[/latex] are the Laplace transforms of [latex]r(t), y(t)[/latex], and [latex]e(t)[/latex], respectively. If the input [latex]r(t)[/latex] is a unit step function, then _____
solution:
Given system is [latex]
G(s)=\frac{6}{s(s+1)(s+2)}
[/latex] The characteristic equation, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
1+G(s) & =0 \\
1+\frac{6}{s(s+1)(s+2)} & =0 \\
s(s+1)(s+2)+6 & =0 \\
s^{3}+3 s^{2}+2 s+6 & =0
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Clearly, here the internal coefficient product is equal to external coefficient product i.e., [latex]
3 \times 2=6 \times 1
[/latex] Hence, the given system is marginally stable system. [latex]\therefore e(t)[/latex] not exist because system is oscillatory system.

options.D: [latex]\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} e(t)[/latex] does not exist, [latex]e(t)[/latex] is oscillatory

Question 15 The open loop transfer function of a unity negative feedback system is [latex]G(s)=\frac{k}{s\left(1+s T_{1}\right)\left(1+s T_{2}\right)}[/latex], where [latex]k, T_{1}[/latex] and [latex]T_{2}[/latex] are positive constants. The phase crossover frequency, in rad/s, is
solution:
We know phase crossover frequency is that frequency at which phase of the open loop transfer function is [latex]-180^{\circ}[/latex]. [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad G(s) & =\frac{K}{s\left(1+s T_{1}\right)\left(1+s T_{2}\right)} \\
G(j \omega) & =\frac{K}{(j \omega)\left(1+j \omega T_{1}\right)\left(1+j \omega T_{2}\right)} \\
\text{Phase of }G(j \omega) & =\phi =-90-\tan ^{-1}\left(\omega T_{1}\right) - \tan ^{-1}\left(\omega T_{2}\right) \\
\therefore \quad \text { At } \omega &=\omega_{p c}, \phi =-180  \\
-180 & =-90-\tan ^{-1}\left(\omega_{p c} T_{1}\right)-\tan ^{-1}\left(\omega_{p c} T_{2}\right) \\
9 \quad 90 & =\tan ^{-1}\left(\omega_{p c} T_{1}\right)+\tan ^{-1}\left(\omega_{p c} T_{2}\right) \\
\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\omega_{p c} T_{1}+\omega_{p c} T_{2}}{1-\omega_{p c}^{2} T_{1} T_{2}}\right) & =90 \\
1-\omega_{p c}^{2} T_{1} T_{2} & =0 \\
\omega_{p c} & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{T_{1} T_{2}}}
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

Question 16 The block diagram of a closed-loop control system is shown in the figure. R(s),Y(s) and D(s) are the Laplace transforms of the time-domain signals [latex]r(t),y(t),[/latex] and [latex]d(t)[/latex], respectively. Let the error signal be defined as [latex]e(t)=r(t)-y(t)[/latex]. Assuming the
reference input [latex]r(t)=0[/latex] for all [latex]t[/latex], the steady-state error [latex]e(\infty )[/latex], due to a unit step
disturbance [latex]d(t)[/latex], is _________ (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution:
[latex]Y(s)=\frac{R(s)\cdot \frac{10}{s(s+10)}}{1+\frac{10}{s(s+10)}} +\frac{D(s)\cdot \frac{10}{s(s+10)}}{1+\frac{10}{s(s+10)}}[/latex] When, 
[latex] r(t)=0\; and \; d(t)=U(t)\underleftrightarrow{L.T.}\frac{1}{s}[/latex] [latex] e(\infty )=-\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{s\cdot \frac{1}{s} \times 1}{s(s+10)+10} =-1/10=-0.1\;\;\;(\because e(t)=r(t)-y(t))[/latex]

Question 17 Two linear time-invariant systems with transfer functions [latex]G_1(s)=\frac{10}{s^2+s+1}, G_2(s)=\frac{10}{s^2+s\sqrt{10}+10} [/latex] have unit step responses [latex]y_1(t) [/latex] and [latex]y_2(t) [/latex], respectively. Which of the following
statements is/are true?
solution:
[latex] \begin{aligned}
G_1(s)&=\frac{10}{s^2+s+1}\\
\omega _{n1}^2&=1\\
2\xi _1 \times 1&=1\\
\xi _1&=1/2\\
G_2(s)&=\frac{10}{s^2+s\sqrt{10}+10}\\
\omega _{n2}^2&=10\\
2\xi _1 \times \sqrt{10}&=\sqrt{10}\\
\xi _2&=1/2\\
\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \because M_P[/latex]  depends on 
[latex]\xi  [/latex] only [latex] y_1(t) \; and \; y_2(t)[/latex] have same percentage peak
overshoot. [latex]\omega _{d_1}=\omega _{n_1}\sqrt{1-\xi ^2} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \omega _{d_1}\neq \omega _{d_2} \;\; \because \omega _{n_1}\neq \omega _{n_2}[/latex] damped frequency of oscillation is not same. [latex] \begin{aligned}
T_s &=\frac{4}{\xi \omega _n}(2%\; setting \; time) \\ 
T_{s_1} &\neq  T_{s_2} \;\because \omega _{n_1}\neq \omega _{n_2}\\ 
C_1(s) &= \frac{10 \times 1/s}{s^2+s+1}\\ 
C_{ss} &=\lim_{s \to 0}s\cdot C_1(s) \\ 
 &= 10\\ 
C_2(s) &= \frac{10 \times 1/s}{s^2+\sqrt{10}s+10}\\ 
C_{ss} &=\lim_{s \to 0}s\cdot C_2(s) \\ 
 &= \frac{10}{10}1=1
\end{aligned}[/latex] Steady - state value is not same.

options.A: [latex]y_1(t)[/latex] and [latex]y_2(t)[/latex] have the same percentage peak overshoot.
options.B: [latex]y_1(t)[/latex] and [latex]y_2(t)[/latex] have the same steady-state value.
options.C: [latex]y_1(t)[/latex] and [latex]y_2(t)[/latex] have the same damped frequency of oscillation.
options.D: [latex]y_1(t)[/latex] and [latex]y_2(t)[/latex] have the same 2% settling time.

Question 18 Consider an even polynomial [latex]p(s)  [/latex] given by [latex]p(s)=s^4+5s^2+4+K [/latex], where [latex]K[/latex] is an unknown real parameter. The complete range of[latex]K[/latex] for which [latex]p(s)  [/latex] has
all its roots on the imaginary axis is ________.
solution:
[latex]p(s)=s^4+5s^2+4+k [/latex] [latex] \begin{matrix}
s^4 &  1& 5 &(4+k) \\ 
 s^3& 0 & 0 & \\ 
 s^2&  &  & \\ 
 s&  &  & \\ 
 s^0&  &  & 
\end{matrix}[/latex] [latex] s^4+5s^2+(4+k)=0[/latex] [latex] 4s^3+10s=0[/latex] [latex](4s^2+10)=0 [/latex] [latex]s=\pm j\sqrt{5/2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{matrix}
s^4 &  1& 5 &(4+k) \\ 
 s^3& 4 & 10 & \\ 
 s^2& 5/2 & (4+k) & \\ 
 s^1&10-\frac{4(4+k)}{5/2}  &  & \\ 
 s^0& (4+k) &  & 
\end{matrix}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}
(4+k) & \gt 0\\
k & \gt -4\\
10 \times \frac{5}{2}& \gt 4(4+K)\\
(4+K)& \lt \frac{25}{4}\\
K& \lt 9/4
\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow  [/latex]  All roots be on imaginary axis 
[latex] -4\leq K\leqslant 9/4[/latex]

For K = 2, point A will be -0.8x2 = -1.6 Hence N = -2, P = 0 (By default Nyquist contoure is considered in

question:
Question 21 A unity feedback system that uses proportional-integral ([latex]\text{PI}[/latex]
) control is shown in the figure. The stability of the overall system is controlled by tuning the [latex]\text{PI}[/latex] control parameters [latex]K_{P}[/latex]
 and [latex]K_{I}[/latex]. The maximum value of [latex]K_{I}[/latex]
 that can be chosen so as to keep the overall system stable or, in the worst case, marginally stable (rounded off to three decimal places) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G H &=\left(\frac{s K_{p}+K_{I}}{s}\right)\left(\frac{2}{s^{3}+4 s^{2}+5 s+2}\right) \\ q(s) &=s^{4}+4 s^{3}+5 s^{2}+s\left(2+2 k_{p}\right)+2 k_{I} \\ \text{Necessary}:\qquad K_{p} & \gt -1 ; K_{I} \gt 0\\ &\begin{array}{l|ccc} s^{4} & 1 & 5 & 2 K_{I} \\ s^{3} & 4 & 2+2 K_{p} & \\ s^{2} & \frac{18-2 K_{p}}{4} & 2 K_{I} & \\ s^{1} & \left(9-K_{p}\right)\left(1+K_{p}\right)-8 K_{I} & & \\ s^{0} & 2 K_{I} & & \end{array}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Sufficient: [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{18-2 K_{p}}{4}& \gt 0\\ \Rightarrow \quad K_{p}& \lt 9\\ \therefore \quad-1& \lt K_{p} \lt 9\\ \left(18-2 K_{p}\right)\left(2+2 K_{p}\right)-32 K_{I}& \gt 0\\ 32 K_{I}& \lt 36+32 K_{p}-4 K_{p}^{2}\\ \therefore \qquad \qquad 0& \lt K_{I} \lt \frac{36+32 K_{p}-4 K_{p}^{2}}{32} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{If }K_{p}&=-1 \Rightarrow k_{I}=0\\ \text{If }K_{p}&=9 \Rightarrow k_{I}=0\\ \end{aligned}[/latex], [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \qquad \qquad \frac{d K_{I}}{d K_{p}}&=0\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad 32-8 K_{p}&=0=0 \Rightarrow K_{p}=4 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] For [latex]K_{p}=4, K_{I}[/latex] is maximum, which is [latex] K_{I}=\frac{36+32 \times 4-64}{32}=3.125[/latex] For [latex]K_{p}=4, K_{I} \lt 3.125[/latex] for stability [latex] \therefore K_{I \max }=3.125[/latex]

question: Question 22 The electrical system shown in the figure converts input source current [latex]i_{s}(t)[/latex] to output voltage [latex]v_{o}(t)[/latex] Current i [latex]i_{L}(t)[/latex] in the inductor and voltage [latex]v_{c}(t)[/latex] across the capacitor are taken as the state variables, both assumed to be initially equal to zero, i.e., [latex]i_{L}(0) =0[/latex] and [latex]v_{c}(0)=0[/latex]. The system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} i_{s} &=v_{i}+v_{c} \\ \therefore \qquad v_{i} &=-v_{c}+i_{s} \\ v_{L} &=L i_{L} \\ v_{L} &=\left(i_{s}-i_{L}\right) \\ \therefore \qquad L i_{L} &=i_{s}-i_{L} \\ \therefore \qquad i_{L} &=-i_{L}+i_{s} \\ v_{o} &=v_{c} \\ X &=\left[\begin{array}{cc} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{array}\right] X+\left[\begin{array}{ll} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] U \\ Y &=[0 \quad 1] X+[0] \cup \\ A &=-I \\ Q_{C} &=\left[\begin{array}{ll} B & A B \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{ll} 1 & -1 \\ 1 & -1 \end{array}\right] \Rightarrow\left|Q_{c}\right|=0 \\ Q_{o} &=\left[\begin{array}{ll} C^{T} & A^{\top} C^{\top} \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 0 \\ 1 & -1 \end{array}\right] \Rightarrow\left|Q_{o}\right|=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: completely state controllable as well as completely observable
options.B: completely state controllable but not observable
options.C: completely observable but not state controllable

Question 25 Consider the following closed loop control system where [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+1)}[/latex] and [latex]C(s)=K\frac{s+1}{s+3}[/latex].
If the steady state error for a unit ramp input
is 0.1, then the value of K is _______.
solution: Open loop transfer function for the system [latex]=C(s)\times G(s)=\frac{K(s+1)}{ (s+3)}\times \frac{1}{s(s+1)}[/latex] Since the system is type-1, so far a given unit ramp input steady state [latex]e_{ss}=\frac{1}{K_{V}} [/latex] where,  [latex]K_{V}=\lim_{s\rightarrow 0}S\times \frac{K}{S(S+3)}=\frac{K}{3} [/latex] so, [latex]\; e_{ss}=\frac{1}{K/3}=\frac{3}{K}[/latex] Given that,  [latex]\; e_{ss}=0.1 [/latex] So, [latex]0.1=\frac{3}{K}\Rightarrow K=30[/latex]

question:
Question 26 A system with transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{(s+1)(s+a)}, a \gt 0[/latex] is subjected an input [latex]5\cos 3t[/latex].
The steady state output of the system is [latex]\frac{1}{\sqrt{10}} \cos (3t-1.892)[/latex]. The value of [latex]a[/latex] is ____.
solution: Given that, [latex]\begin{aligned}G(j\omega )&=\frac{1}{(1+j\omega )(\alpha +j\omega )} \\ \left |G(j\omega ) \right |&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{(\omega ^{2}+1)(\omega ^{2}+\alpha ^{2})}} \\ \text{According to }& \text{question,}\\ \left | G(j\omega ) \right |_{\omega =3}&=\frac{1}{5\sqrt{10}}\\ \Rightarrow \frac{1}{\sqrt{(\omega ^{2}+1)(\omega ^{2}+\alpha ^{2})}}&=\frac{1}{5\sqrt{10}} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{1}{\sqrt{10(a^{2}+9)}}&=\frac{1}{5\sqrt{10}} \alpha ^{2}+9=25 \\ \alpha ^{2}&=16 \\ \alpha &=4\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 29 The loop transfer function of a negative feedback system is [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{K(s+11)}{s(s+2)(s+8)}[/latex] The value of K, for which the system is marginally stable, is ________.

The positive value of K for which there are exactly two poles of the unity feedback system on the [latex]j\omega[/latex] axis is equal to ______ (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}=\frac{K}{s^{3}+3 s^{2}+2 s+K} [/latex] Two poles of this system lie the system is moro: System is marginally stable. [latex] \qquad k_{\text{mar}}=3 \times 2=6[/latex]

question: Question 32 Let the state-space representation of an LTI system be [latex]\dot{x}(t)=Ax(t)+Bu(t)[/latex],  [latex]\dot{y}(t)=Cx(t)+du(t)[/latex]  where A, B, C are matrices, d is a scalar, u(t) is the input to the system, and y(t) is its output. Let [latex]B=[0\;0\;1]^T[/latex] and d=0. Which one of the following options for A and C will ensure that the transfer function of this LTI system is [latex]H(s)=\frac{1}{s^3+3s^2+2s+1}[/latex]?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} X(t) &=A x(t)+B u(t) \\ y(t) &=C x(t) \\ B &=\left[\begin{array}{l} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \\ \frac{\gamma(s)}{U(s)} &=\\ \frac{\gamma(s)}{X_{1}(s)} \times \frac{X_{1}(s)}{U(s)}=& 1 \times \frac{1}{s^{3}+3 s^{2}+2 s+1} \\ x_{1}(s)\left(s^{3}+3 s^{2}+2 s+1\right]&=U(s) \\ x_{2} &=\dot{x}_{1}(t) \\ x_{2}(s) &=s x_{1}(s) \\ x_{3} &=\dot{x}_{2}(t) \\ \Rightarrow \quad x_{3}(s) &=s x_{2}(s)=s^{2} X_{1}(s) \\ \text { So, } \quad s x_{3}(s) &=-x_{1}(s)-2 x_{2}(s)-3 x_{3}(s)+u(s) \\ \dot{x}_{3}(t) &=-x_{1}(t)-2 r_{2}(t)-3 x_{3}(t)+u(t) \\ y(t) &=x_{1}(t) \\ \dot{x}(t) &=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ -1 & -2 & -3\end{array}\right] x(t)+\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 0 \\ 1\end{array}\right] u(t) \\ y(t) &=[1 \quad 0 \quad 0] x(t) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 34 Consider a causal second-order system with the transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{1+2s+s^2}[/latex] with a unit-step [latex]R(s)=\frac{1}{s}[/latex] as an input. Let C(s) be the corresponding output. The time taken by the system output c(t) to reach 94% of its steady-state value [latex]\lim_{t \to \infty }c(t)[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places, is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G(s)&=\frac{1}{s^{2}+2 s+1}=\frac{1}{(s+1)^{2}} \\ R(s)&=\frac{1}{s} \\ \alpha (s)&=G(s) R(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+1)^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Using partial fraction expansion, we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} C(s) & =\frac{A}{s}+\frac{B}{(s+1)}+\frac{C}{(s+1)^{2}} \\ A\left(s^{2}+2 s+1\right)&+B\left(s^{2}+s\right)+C s=1 \\ A&=1 \\ A+B & =0 \Rightarrow B=-1 \\ 2 A+B+C & =0 \Rightarrow C=-1 \\ \therefore \quad C(s) & =\frac{1}{s}-\frac{1}{(s+1)}-\frac{1}{(s+1)^{2}} \\ \text{and}\quad c(t) & =\left(1-e^{-t}-t e^{-t}\right) u(t) \\ \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} c(t) & =1 \end{aligned}[/latex] In order to reach 94 % of its steady-state value, [latex] \left(1-e^{-t}-t e^{-t}\right)=0.94[/latex] By trial and error, we get, [latex] t \approx 4.50 \mathrm{sec}[/latex]

question: Question 35 For an LTI system, the Bode plot for its gain is as illustrated in the figure shown. The number of system poles [latex]N_p[/latex] and the number of system zeros [latex]N_z[/latex] in the frequency range [latex]1Hz\leq f\leq 10^7Hz[/latex] is
solution: Number of poles [latex](N_{P})[/latex]= 6 Number of zeros [latex](N_{Z})[/latex] = 3

question: Question 36 The figure below shows the Bode magnitude and phase plots of a stable transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{n_{o}}{s^{2}+d_{2}s^{2}+d_{1}+d_{0}}[/latex] Consider the negative unity feedback configuration with gain k in the feedforward path. The closed loop is stable for [latex] k \lt k_{o} [/latex]. The maximum value of [latex]k_{o} [/latex] is ______.
solution: For G(s) [latex] M_{\mathrm{dB}}\left(\omega_{p c}\right)=20 \mathrm{dB} [/latex] When cascaded with k , [latex] \begin{aligned} \mathrm{GM}_{\mathrm{dB}} &=-20 \mathrm{dB}-20 \log _{10}(k) \gt 0 \mathrm{dB} \\ 20+20 \log _{10}(k) & \lt 0 \\ 20 \log _{10}(k) & \lt -20 \\ k & \lt 10^{-1}=0.10\\ \text{So,}\quad k_{0}&=0.10 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 37 For a unity feedback control system with the forward path transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+2)}[/latex] The peak resonant magnitude [latex]M_{r}[/latex], of the closed-loop frequency response is 2. The corresponding value of the gain K (correct to two decimal places) is _________.
solution: Maximum resonant peak, [latex]\begin{aligned} M_{r} &=\frac{1}{2 \xi \sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}}=2 \\ 2 \xi \sqrt{1-\xi^{2}} &=\frac{1}{2} \\ \xi^{2}\left(1-\xi^{2}\right) &=\frac{1}{16} \\ \xi^{4}-\xi^{2}+\frac{1}{16} &=0 \\ \xi^{2}&=\frac{1}{2} \pm \sqrt{\frac{1-\frac{1}{4}}{4}}=\frac{1}{2} \pm \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \\ \text { As } M_{r}=2 \gt 1, \xi& \lt \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \text { and } \xi^{2} \lt \frac{1}{2} \\ \text { So. } \quad\xi^{2}&=\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\\ Given, \quad G(s)&=\frac{K}{s(s+2)}=\frac{\omega_{n}^{2}}{s\left(s+2 \xi \omega_{n}\right)} \\ \text{So} \quad\omega_{n} &=\sqrt{K} \\ 2 \xi \sqrt{K} &=2\\ \sqrt{K} &=\frac{1}{\xi} \\ K &=\frac{1}{\xi^{2}}=\frac{1}{\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\right)} \\ &=\frac{4}{2-\sqrt{3}}=14.928 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 38 The state equation and the output equation of a control system are given below: [latex]\dot{x}=\begin{bmatrix} -4 & -1.5\\ 4 & 0 \end{bmatrix}x+\begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 0\end{bmatrix}u,[/latex] [latex]y=\begin{bmatrix} 1.5 & 0.625 \end{bmatrix}x.[/latex] The transfer function representation of the system is
solution: Transfer function [latex]\begin{aligned} T(s) &=\frac{Y(s)}{U(s)}=\mathrm{C}(s I-A]^{-1} \mathrm{B} \\ A &=\left[\begin{array}{cc} -4 & -1.5 \\ 4 & 0 \end{array}\right] \\ B &=\left[\begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \\ C&=[1.5\quad0.625]\\ {[s I-A]} & =\left[\begin{array}{cc}s+4 & 1.5 \\-4 & s\end{array}\right] \\ {[s I-A]^{-1}} & =\frac{1}{\left(s^{2}+4 s+6\right)}\left[\begin{array}{cc}s & -1.5 \\4 & s+4 \end{array}\right] \\ {[s I-A]^{-1} B} & =\frac{1}{s^{2}+4 s+6}\left[\begin{array}{c}2 s \\8 \end{array}\right] & \\ C[s I-A]^{-1} B & =\frac{1}{s^{2}+4 s+6}[1.5 \quad 0.625]\left[\begin{array}{c}2 s \\ 8\end{array}\right] \\ T(s) & =\frac{3 s+5}{s^{2}+4 s+6} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 39 The Nyquist stability criterion and the Routh criterion both are powerful analysis tools for
determining the stability of feedback controllers. Identify which of the following statements
is FALSE:

options.A: Both the criteria provide information relative to the stable gain range of the system.
options.B:
The general shape of the Nyquist plot is readily obtained from the Bode magnitude plot
for all minimum-phase systems.
options.C:
The Routh criterion is not applicable in the condition of transport lag, which can be
readily handled by the Nyquist criterion.
options.D:
The closed-loop frequency response for a unity feedback system cannot be obtained
from the Nyquist plot.

question: Question 40 A second - order LTI system is described by the following state equations, [latex]\frac{d}{dt}x_{1}(t)- x_{2}(t)=0[/latex] [latex]\frac{d}{dt}x_{2}(t)+2x_{1}(t)+3x_{2}(t)=r(t)[/latex] Where [latex] x_{1}(t)[/latex] and  [latex]x_{2}(t)[/latex] are the two state variables and r(t) denotes the input. The output  [latex] c(t) =x_{1}(t)[/latex]. The system is.
solution:
Given state variable equations are as follows: [latex] \begin{aligned} &\frac{d}{d t} x_{1}(t)-x_{2}(t)=0 &\ldots(i)\\ &\frac{d}{d t} x_{2}(t)+2 x_{2}(t)+3 x_{2}(t)=r(t) &\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Also given that, input [latex]=r(t)[/latex] and output [latex]=x_{1}(t) [/latex] By applying Laplace transform to equation (i), we get, [latex] s X_{1}(s)=X_{2}(s) \qquad \ldots(iii)[/latex] By applying Laplace transform to equation (ii). we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} s X_{2}(s)+2 X_{1}(s)+3 X_{2}(s)&=R(s) \\ x_{2}(s)&=\frac{R(s)-2 X_{1}(s)}{s+3} &\ldots(iv) \end{aligned}[/latex] By substituting equation (iv) in equation (iii), we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} s X_{\mathrm{i}}(s)&=\frac{R(s)-2 X_{1}(s)}{s+3}\\ \left(s^{2}+3 s+2\right) X_{1}(s)&=R(s) \end{aligned}[/latex] So, the transfer function of the given system is, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\frac{X_{1}(s)}{R(s)} &=\frac{1}{s^{2}+3 s+2} \\
v r^{2} &=2 \\
2 \zeta_{n} &=3 \\
\xi &=\frac{3}{2 \omega_{n}}=\frac{3}{2 \sqrt{2}}=1.06
\end{aligned}[/latex] As  [latex]\xi \gt 1,[/latex]  the given system is overdamped.

question: Question 41 A unity feedback control system is characterized by the open-loop transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{2(s+1)}{s^{3}+ks^{2}+2s+1}[/latex] The value of k for which the system oscillates at 2 rad/s is ________.
solution: The given open loop transfer function is, [latex] G(s)=\frac{2(s+1)}{s^{3}+K s^{2}+2 s+1}[/latex] The closed loop transfer function is, [latex] T(s)=\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s)}=\frac{2(s+1)}{s^{3}+K s^{2}+4 s+3}[/latex] When system oscillates, i.e., when system is marginally stable, [latex] (1)(3)=K(4) [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{So}, \quad K=0.75[/latex]

question: Question 42 A unity feedback control system is characterized by the open-loop transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{10K(s+2)}{s^{3}+3s^{2}+10}[/latex] The Nyquist path and the corresponding Nyquist plot of G(s) are shown in the figures below. If [latex]0 \lt K \lt 1[/latex], then the number of poles of the closed-loop transfer function that lie in the right half of the s-plane is
solution:
Given that, the open loop transfer function of a  unity feedback system is, [latex] G(s) =\frac{10 k(s+2)}{s^{3}+3 s^{2}+10} [/latex] From the given Nyquist plot, for [latex]0 \lt k \lt 1[/latex] the encirclements about the point (-1+j 0) is, [latex] \begin{array}{l} N=0 \\ N=P-Z \end{array}[/latex] P= number of open loop poles in the right half of s-plane Z= number of closed loop poles in the right half of s-plane To determine the value of P : Applying R-H criteria to G(s) [latex] G(s)=\frac{10 k(s+2)}{s^{3}+3 s^{2}+10}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{c|cc} s^{3} & 1 & 0 \\ s^{2} & 3 & 10 \\ s^{1} & -10 / 3 & 0 \\ s^{0} & 10 & 0 \end{array}[/latex] Two sign changes are there in the first column of 
the RH table. So, two open loop poles are there in 
right half of s-plane. So, [latex]
P=2[/latex] [latex]
\begin{array}{l}
N=P-Z \\
0=2-Z \\
Z=2
\end{array}[/latex] Z=2 indicates, there are two closed loop poles 
in right half of s-plane.

question: Question 43 For the system shown in the figure, Y(s)/X(s)= __________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Y(s) &=[X(s)-Y(s)] G(s)+X(s) \\ [1+G(s)] Y(s) &=[G(s)+1] X(s) \\ \frac{Y(s)}{X(s)} &=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 44 Which of the following statements is incorrect?
solution:
In_ case of high type systems Lag compensator 
fails to give stability.

options.A: Lead compensator is used to reduce the settling time.
options.B: Lag compensator is used to reduce the steady state error.
options.C: Lead compensator may increase the order of a system.
options.D: Lag compensator always stabilizes an unstable system.

question: Question 45 Consider the state space realization [latex]\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}(t)\\ x_{2}(t) \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0\\ 0&-9 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_{1}(t)\\ x_{2}(t) \end{bmatrix}+ \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 45 \end{bmatrix}u(t)[/latex] , with the initial condition [latex]\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}(0)\\ x_{2}(0) \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] where u(t) denotes the unit step function. The value of  [latex]\lim_{t\rightarrow \infty }|\sqrt{x_{1}^{2}(t)+x_{2}^{2}(t)}|[/latex]  is _______.
solution: [latex]\left[\begin{array}{l} \dot{x}_{1}(t) \\ \dot{x}_{2}(t) \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -9 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l} x_{1}(t) \\ x_{2}(t) \end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 45 \end{array}\right] u(t)[/latex] By applying Laplace transform on both sides. get [latex] \begin{aligned} s x_{1}(s)-x_{1}(0)&=0\\ X_{1}(s)&=\frac{x_{1}(0)}{s}=0 \quad \because x_{1}(0)=0 \\ \text{So,} x_{1}(t)&=0 \\ \text{and }\quad s X_{\lambda}(s)-x_{2}(0)&=-9 X_{1}(s)+\frac{45}{s} \\ X_{2}(s) &=\frac{45}{s(s+9)} \quad \because x_{2}(0)=0 \\ \text { Required value } &=\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty}|\sqrt{x_{1}^{2}(t)+x_{2}^{2}(t)}| \\ &=\left|\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} x_{2}(t)\right| \quad \because x_{1}(t)=0 \\ \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} x_{2}(t) &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s X_{2}(s)=\frac{45}{9}=5 \end{aligned}[/latex] So, Required value [latex]= |5| =5[/latex]

question: Question 46 The Nyquist plot of the transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{(s^{2}+2s+2)(s+2)}[/latex] does not encircle the point (1+j0) for K=10 but does encircle the point (-1+j0) for K=100. Then the closed loop system (having unity gain feedback) is

question:
Question 52 The forward-path transfer function and the feedback-path transfer function of a single loop negative feedback control system are given as [latex]G(s)=\frac{K(s+2)}{s^{2}+2s+2}[/latex] and H(s)=1, respectively. If the variable parameter K is real positive, then the location of the breakaway point on
the root locus diagram of the system is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G(s) &=\frac{K(s+2)}{s^{2}+2 s+2} \\ H(s)&=1 \\ 1+G(s) H(s) &=0 \\ 1+\frac{K}{\left(s^{2}\right)+2 s+2}(s+2) &=0\\ K&=-\frac{\left(s^{2}+2 s+2\right)}{(s+2)} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \frac{d K}{d s}=-\left(\frac{(2 s+2)(s+2)-\left(s^{2}+2 s+2\right)}{(s+2)^{2}}\right) [/latex] For break away points, [latex] \frac{d K}{d s}=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} (2 s+2)(s+2)-\left(s^{2}+2 s+2\right)=0 \\ 2 s^{2}+6 s+4-s^{2}-2 s-2=0 \\ s^{2}+4 s+2=0 \end{array} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} s&=\frac{-4 \pm \sqrt{16-8}}{2} \\ &=\frac{-4 \pm 2 \sqrt{2}}{2}=-2 \pm \sqrt{2} \\ s&=-0.58 ; s=-3.41 \\ \text{But,}\quad s&=-3.41 \text{ lies on root locus }\\ \text{Hence}\quad s&=-3.41 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 54 The first two rows in the Routh table for the characteristic equation of a certain closed-loop control system are given as The range of K for which the system is stable is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c|cc} s^{3}& 1 & (2 k+3) \\ s^{2}&2 k & 4 \\ s&\frac{4 k^{2}+6 k-4}{2 k} & 0\\ s^{0}&4 \end{array}[/latex] For stability, [latex]K \gt 0[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} 4 K^{2}+6 K-4& \gt 0 \\ 2 K^{2}+3 K-2& \gt 0 \\ (2 K-1)(K+2)& \gt 0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad K& \gt \frac{1}{2} or, k \lt -2 \\ \text{Hence, }\quad 0.5& \lt K \lt \infty \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 55 For the unity feedback control system shown in the figure, the open-loop transfer function G(s) is given as [latex]G(s)=\frac{2}{s(s+1)}[/latex] . The steady state error [latex]e_{ss}[/latex] due to a unit step input is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} E(s) &=\frac{R(s)}{1+G(s) H(s)} \\ R(s) &=\frac{1}{s} ; G(s)=\frac{2}{s(s+1)}; \\ H(s) &=1 \\ E(s) &=\frac{\frac{1}{s}}{1+\frac{s}{s(s+1)}}=\frac{s+1}{s^{2}+s+2} \\ e_{s s} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s E(s) \\ &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} \frac{s(s+1)}{s^{2}+s+2} \\ e_{s s} &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 58 In the feedback system shown below [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{(s+1)(s+2)(s+3)}[/latex] The positive value of k for which the gain margin of the loop is exactly 0 dB and the phase margin of the loop is exactly zero degree is ________

question: Question 59 In the feedback system shown below [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{(s^{2}+2s)}[/latex]. The step response of the closed-loop system should have minimum settling time and have no overshoot. The required value of gain k to achieve this is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G(s)&=\frac{1}{s^{2}+2 s} \\ \frac{Y(s)}{R(s)}&=\frac{\frac{K}{s^{2}+2 s}}{1+\frac{K}{s^{2}+2 s}}=\frac{K}{s^{2}+2 s+K} \end{aligned}[/latex] Minimum settling time and no overshoot implies critical damping i.e. [latex] \begin{aligned} \xi &=1 \\ \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{K} \\ \therefore \quad 2 \times \xi \cdot \omega_{n} &=2 \\ \omega_{n} &=1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{K} &=1 \text { or } K=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 60 The number and direction of encirclements around the point -1+j0 in the complex plane by the Nyquist plot of [latex]G(s)=\frac{1-s}{4+2s}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{1-s}{4+2 s}[/latex] and [latex]\angle G(s)=-\tan ^{-1} \omega-\tan ^{-1} \frac{\omega}{2}[/latex] at [latex]s=0, \quad|G(s)|=\frac{1}{4}=0.25 [/latex] and [latex]\left.\angle G(s)\right|_{\omega=0}=0^{\circ} [/latex] at [latex]s=\infty, \quad|G(s)|=-\frac{1}{2}=-0.5 [/latex] and [latex]\left.\angle G(s)\right|_{m \times \infty}=-180^{\circ} [/latex] Nyquist plot is Hence, number of encirclements of (-1 + j0) = 0

question: Question 61 The response of the system [latex]G(s)=\frac{s-2}{(s+1)(s+3)}[/latex] to the unit step input u(t) is y(t). The value of [latex]\frac{dy}{dt}[/latex] at t=[latex]0^{+}[/latex] is _________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L\left(\frac{d y}{d t}\right) &=(s Y(s)-y(0)) \\ Y(s) &=G(s) \times \frac{1}{s}=\frac{s-2}{s(s+1)(s+3)} \\ y(0)&=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} s Y(s) \\ \text{(Applying } & \text{initial value theorem) } \\ &=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} \frac{s-2}{(s+1)(s+3)} \\ &=\frac{\left(1-\frac{2}{s}\right)}{s\left(1+\frac{1}{s}\right)\left(1+\frac{3}{s}\right)} \\ y(0)&=0 \\ L\left(\frac{d y}{d t}\right) &=s Y(s)=\frac{s \times(s-2)}{s(s+1)(s+3)} \\ &=\frac{s-2}{(s+1)(s+3)} \\ \left.\frac{d y}{d t}\right|_{t=0} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} s L\left(\frac{d y}{d t}\right) \\ &=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} \frac{s \times(s-2)}{(s+1)(s+3)}\\ &=\frac{\left(1-\frac{2}{s}\right)}{\left(1+\frac{1}{s}\right)\left(1+\frac{3}{s}\right)}=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 62 The transfer function of a linear time invariant system is given by [latex]H(s)=2s^{4}-5s^{3}+5s-2[/latex] The number of zeros in the right half of the s-plane is ________
solution: [latex]2 s^{4}-5 s^{3}+5 s-2=0 [/latex] By Routh Array, [latex] \begin{array}{c|ccc} s^{4} & 2 & 0 & -2 \\ s^{3} & -5 & 5 & \\ s^{2} & 2 & -2 & \\ s^{1} & 0(2) & & \\ s^{0} & -2 & & \end{array}[/latex] Number at sign changes = number at roots (zeros)  in right half of s-plane =3

question: Question 63 The open-loop transfer function of a unity-feedback control system is given by [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+2)}[/latex] For the peak overshoot of the closed-loop system to a unit step input to be 10%, the value of K is____________
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+2)} ; H(s)=1 [/latex] Characteristic equation [latex]=1+G(s) H(s)=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} 1+\frac{K}{s(s+2)} &=0 \\ s^{2}+2 s+K &=0 \Rightarrow \omega_{n}=\sqrt{K} \\ 2 \xi \omega_{n} &=2 ; \xi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}} \\ M_{p}&=e^{-\pi\xi/\sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}}-0.1\\ -\frac{\pi \xi}{\sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}} &=\ln (0.1) \\ \Rightarrow \quad\frac{\pi \xi}{\sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}} &=2.3 \\ \pi^{2} \xi^{2} &=(2.3)^{2}\left(1-\xi^{2}\right) \\ 15.16 \xi^{2} &=(2.3)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \xi&=0.59 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \text{Also}, \quad K&=\frac{1}{\xi^{2}}=2.8 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 64 The open-loop transfer function of a unity-feedback control system is [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s^{2}+5s+5}[/latex] The value of K at the breakaway point of the feedback control system's root-locus plot is ________
solution: Characteristic equation  [latex]1+G(s)H(s)=0[/latex] [latex]1+\frac{K}{s^2+5s+5}=0[/latex] [latex]K=-s^2-5s-5[/latex] For break away point [latex]\frac{dK}{ds}=0[/latex] [latex]\frac{dK}{ds}=-2s+5=0\;\Rightarrow \; s=-2.5[/latex] According to magnitude condition, [latex]\begin{aligned} |G(s)H(s)|_{s=-2.5} &=1 \\ |G(s)H(s)|_{s=-2.5} &=\frac{|K|}{|(2.5)^2 +5 \times -2.5+5|}=1 \\ |K|&=|(6.25+5-12.5)|=1.25 \\ K&=\pm 1.25 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 65 A closed-loop control system is stable if the Nyquist plot of the corresponding open-loop transfer function
solution:
N= P-Z N = Number of encirclements of (-1 + /J). It is
positive if nyquist plot encircles the point -1 + j0 
in counterclockwise direction. Z = Number of closed loop poles lying in the right 
half of s-plane P = Number of open loop poles lying in right half 
of s-plane For stability Z = 0 [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] N = P

options.A: encircles the s-plane point (-1 + j0) in the counterclockwise direction as many times as the number of right-half s-plane poles.
options.B: encircles the s-plane point (0 - j1) in the clockwise direction as many times as the number of right-half s-plane poles.

question: Question 66 Match the inferences X, Y, and Z, about a system, to the corresponding properties of the elements of first column in Routh?s Table of the system characteristic equation.
solution:
When all elements are positive, the system is 
stable. When any element is zero, the test breaks 
down. When there is change in sign of 
coefficients, the system is unstable.

question: Question 67 The characteristic equation of an LTI system is given by [latex]F(s)=s^{5}+2s^{4}+3s^{3}+6s^{2}-4s-8=0[/latex] The number of roots that lie strictly in the left half s-plane is _________.
solution: Using Routh's tabular or: [latex] \begin{array}{c|lll} s^{5} & 1 & 3 & -4 \\ s^{4} & 2 & 6 & -8 \\ s^{3} & 0 8 & 0(12) & 0 \\ s^{2} & 3 & -8 & 0 \\ s^{1} & \frac{100}{3} & 0 & 0 \\ s^{0} & -8 & & \end{array}[/latex] Auxiliary equation: [latex] \begin{aligned} A &=2 s^{4}+6 s^{2}-8=0 \\ \frac{d A}{d s} &=8 s^{3}+12 s=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] As one time row of zero occur in Routh's table therefore a pair of imaginary pole exists, also  number of sign change in Routh's table is one. Hence, two poles lie strictly in the left half of s-plane.

question: Question 68 For the system shown in the figure, s = -2.75 lies on the root locus if K is _______.
solution: The open loop transfer function of the system: [latex] G(s) H(s)=\frac{K(s+3) \times 10}{(s+2)}[/latex] In order to lie a point s=-2.75, the angle condition must be satisfy and therefore the magnitude condition is [latex] \begin{aligned} &\mid G(s) H(s) \|_{s=-275}=1 \\ &=\left.\frac{10 K \sqrt{s^{2}+3^{2}}}{\sqrt{s^{2}+2^{2}}}\right|_{s=-2.75}=1 \\ &=\frac{10 K \sqrt{(3-2.75)^{2}}}{\sqrt{(2-2.75)^{2}}}=1 \\ &=\frac{0.25 \times 10 K}{0.75} or K=0.3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 69 The position control of a DC servo-motor is given in the figure. The values of the parameters are [latex]K_{T}=1 N-m/A[/latex], [latex]R_{a}=1 \Omega [/latex], [latex] L_{a}=0.1H,J=5kg-m^{2} [/latex], [latex]B=1 N-m(rad/sec)[/latex] and [latex] K_b=1V/(rad/sec)[/latex] . The steady-state position response (in radians) due to unit impulse disturbance torque [latex]T_{d}[/latex] is_______.
solution: The transfer function due to the disturbance torque [latex] T_{d}(s) \text { is } [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\theta(s)}{T_{d}(s)}&=\frac{-\frac{1}{(J s+B)} \times \frac{1}{s}}{1+\left(\frac{1}{J s+B}\right)\left(\frac{K_{b} K_{T}}{R_{a}+L_{a} s}\right)} \\ &=\frac{-\left(R_{a}+L_{a} s\right) \cdot \frac{1}{s}}{\left(R_{a}+L_{a} s\right)(J s+B)+K_{b} K_{T}} \end{aligned}[/latex] The steady value of response for unit impulse input [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{-s\left(R_{a}+L_{a} s\right) \cdot \frac{1}{s}}{\left(R_{a}+L_{a} s\right)(J s+B)+K_{b} K_{T}}.T_{d}\\ &=-\frac{R_{a}}{R_{a} B+K_{b} K_{T}} \cdot 1\\ \text{Given:}\\ K_{T}&=1 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{A} R_{a}=1 \Omega \\ B&=1 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec}\\ \text{and }\quad K_{b}&=1 \mathrm{V} / \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex] Substituting the given values into above equation,  we get [latex] \theta(0)=-\frac{1}{2}=-0.5 \mathrm{rad}[/latex]

question: Question 70 A network is described by the state model as [latex]\dot{x_1}=2x_{1}-x_{2}+3u [/latex] [latex]\dot{x_2}=-4x_{2}-u[/latex] [latex] y=3x_{1}-2x_{2}[/latex] The transfer function [latex]H(s)(=\frac{Y(s)}{U(s)})[/latex] is
solution: State matrix form: [latex] \begin{array}{l} \dot{x}=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 & -1 \\ 0 & -4 \end{array}\right] x+\left[\begin{array}{c} 3 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] u \\ y=\left[\begin{array}{ll} 3 & -2 \end{array}\right] x \end{array}[/latex] The transfer function from tate matrix can be calculated as: [latex] T(S)=C(s l-A]^{-1} B+D[/latex] Here, [latex] [s l-A]^{-1}=\left[\begin{array}{cc} s-2 & 1 \\ 0 & s+4 \end{array}\right]^{-1}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{1}{(s-2)(s+4)}\left[\begin{array}{cc} (s+4) & -1 \\ 0 & (s-2) \end{array}\right] \\ \Rightarrow &C[s /-A]^{-1} B \\ =& \frac{1}{(s-2)(s+4)}[3-2]\left[\begin{array}{cc} (s+4) & -1 \\ 0 & (s-2) \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} 3 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] \\ =& \frac{1}{(s-2)(s+4)}[3-2]\left[\begin{array}{c} 3 s+12+1 \\ -s+2 \end{array}\right] \\ =& \frac{1}{(s-2)(s+4)}[9 s+39+2 s-4] \\ =& \frac{11 s+35}{(s-2)(s+4)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 71 The transfer function of a first-order controller is given as [latex]G_{c}(s)=\frac{K(s+a)}{s+b}[/latex] where K, a and b are positive real numbers. The condition for this controller to act as a phase lead compensator is
solution: For phase lead compensator [latex] \begin{aligned} G_{c}(s)&=\frac{(1+s \tau)}{(1+\alpha s \tau)} \quad ; \quad \alpha \lt 1\\ \text{Here,}\quad \tau&=\frac{1}{a}\\ \text{and}\quad \alpha \tau&=\frac{1}{b}\\ \text{or,}\quad \alpha&=\frac{a}{b} \lt 1\\ \text{or,}\quad a& \lt b \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 72 The phase margin (in degrees) of the system [latex]G(s)=\frac{10}{s(s+10)}[/latex] is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G(s) &=\frac{10}{s(s+10)} \\ P M &=180^{\circ}+\left.\angle G(\omega) H(\omega)\right|_{\omega=\omega_{g c}} \end{aligned} [/latex] The gain cross over frequency can be calculated by [latex] \begin{aligned} |G(\omega) H(\omega)|&=1 \\ \frac{10}{\omega \sqrt{\omega^{2}+100}}&=1 \\ \omega_{g c}^{4}+100 \omega_{g c}^{2}&-100=0\\ \text { Or } \quad \omega_{g c}^{2}&=0.99, \quad-100.99 \\ \text { Or } \quad \omega_{g c}&=0.99 \text { rad/sec. } \\ \therefore P M &=180^{\circ}+\left(-90^{\circ}-\tan ^{-1} \frac{\omega_{g c}}{10}\right) \\ &=180^{\circ}-90^{\circ}-\tan ^{-1} \frac{0.99}{10} \\ & \simeq 84.364^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 73 Consider the Bode plot shown in the figure. Assume that all the poles and zeros are real-valued. The value of [latex]f_{H}-f_{L}[/latex] (in Hz) is ___________.
solution: As we know, [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Slope } &=\frac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}} \\ \therefore \quad 40 \mathrm{dB} / \mathrm{dec} &=\frac{40-0}{\log 300-\log _{L}}\\ or, \log \left(\frac{300}{f_{L}}\right)&=\frac{40}{40}=1 f_{L}=30 \mathrm{Hz} \end{aligned}[/latex] Similarly, [latex] \begin{aligned} -40 \mathrm{dB} / \mathrm{dec}&=\frac{40-0}{\log 900-\log f_{H}}\\ \log \left(\frac{900}{f_{H}}\right) &=-1 \\ \text { or, } \quad f_{H}&=9000 \mathrm{Hz} \\ \text { Therefore, } f_{H}-f_{L}&=9000-30 =8970 \mathrm{Hz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 74 The transfer function of a mass-spring-damper system is given by [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{Ms^{2}+Bs+K}[/latex] The frequency response data for the system are given in the following table. The unit step response of the system approaches a steady state value of ________ .
solution: [latex]\frac{\alpha(s)}{R(s)}=G(s)=\frac{1}{M s^{2}+B s+K} [/latex] Steady state value of response for unit step input [latex] \begin{aligned} C(s)&=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s \times \frac{1}{M s^{2}+B s+K} \times \frac{1}{s}=\frac{1}{K} \\ \text{Also}&\\ G(\approx 0)&=\frac{1}{K}=-18.5 \mathrm{dB} \\ &\qquad\text{(as per the given table)}\\ \therefore \frac{1}{K}&=10^{\left(-\frac{18.5}{20}\right)}=0.12 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 75 The output of a standard second-order system for a unit step input is given as [latex]y(t)=1-\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}e^{-t}cos(\sqrt{3}t-\frac{\pi }{6})[/latex]. The transfer function of the system is
solution: The output of a second order system for unit step input [latex] y(t)=1-\frac{e^{-\xi \omega_{n} t}}{\sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}} \sin \left(\omega_{d} t-\theta\right) \qquad\ldots(i)[/latex] From given data [latex] \begin{aligned} y(t)&=1-\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} e^{-t} \cos \left(\sqrt{3} t-\frac{\pi}{6}\right)\\ \therefore \quad \alpha&=\xi \omega_{n}=1 \\ \text{and }\quad \omega_{d}&=\sqrt{3} \\ \omega_{n}&=\sqrt{\alpha^{2}+\omega_{d}^{2}}=2 \\ \xi&=\frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, the transfer function [latex] T(s)=\frac{\omega_{n}^{2}}{s^{2}+2 \xi \omega_{n} s+\omega_{n}^{2}}=\frac{4}{s^{2}+2 s+4}[/latex]

question: Question 76 The state variable representation of a system is given as [latex]x=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1\\ 0&-1 \end{bmatrix}x; \; x(0)=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \; y= \begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 \end{bmatrix}x[/latex] The response y(t) is
solution: The response of the system is given by [latex] x(t)=L^{-1}\left[(s l-A)^{-1} x(0)+(s /-A)^{-1} B \cdot U(s)\right] [/latex] and the complete response [latex] y(t)=[C] x(t) [/latex] From the given state model, [latex] \begin{array}{l} A=\left[\begin{array}{ll}0 & 1 \\ 0 & -1\end{array}\right] ; B=0: C=[0 \quad 1] \; and \;  x(0)=\left[\begin{array}{c}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right] \\ \therefore \quad(s l-A)^{-1}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}s & -1 \\ 0 & s+1\end{array}\right]^{-1} \\ =\frac{1}{s(s+1)}\left[\begin{array}{cc}s+1 & 1 \\ 0 & s\end{array}\right] \\ (s l-A)^{-1} x(0)=\frac{1}{s(s+1)}\left[\begin{array}{cc} s+1 & 1 \\ 0 & s \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \\ =\frac{1}{s(s+1)}\left[\begin{array}{c} s+1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 / s \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \\ \Rightarrow x(t)=L^{-1}\left[(s I-A)^{-1} x(0)\right] \\ =\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] u(t) \end{array}[/latex] and the complete response [latex] y(t)=\left[\begin{array}{lll}0 & 1\end{array}\right] x(t)=\left[\begin{array}{ll}0 & 1\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right]=0[/latex]

question: Question 77 A unity negative feedback system has an open-loop transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+10)}[/latex]. The gain for the system to have a damping ratio of 0.25 is ________.
solution: [latex]T(s)=\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s) H(s)}=\frac{K}{s^{2}+10 s+K} [/latex] Comparing with standard second order transfer  function [latex] \begin{aligned} T(s)&=\frac{\omega_{n}^{2}}{s^{2}+2 \xi \omega_{n} s+\omega_{n}^{2}}\\ \text{We have, }\omega_{n}^{2}&=K \\ \text{and }\quad 2 \xi \omega_{n}&=10 \\ \because \quad \xi&=0.25 \quad (given)\\ \therefore \quad \omega_{n}&=\frac{10}{2 \times 0.25}=20 \\ \text{and }\quad k&=\omega_{n}^{2}=(20)^{2}=400 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 79 By performing cascading and/or summing/differencing operations using transfer function blocks [latex]G_{1}(s) \; and \;  G_{2}(s)[/latex], one CANNOT realize a transfer function of the form
solution: Given blocks has transfer function [latex]G_{1}(s)[/latex] and [latex] G_{2}(s) [/latex] In cascade connection [latex] G_{1}(s) \cdot G_{2}(s) [/latex] In parallel connection [latex]G_{1}(s)+G_{2}(s) [/latex] From the given options: (For cascading/ summing/differncing) (A) [latex]G_{1}(s) G_{2}(s) \Rightarrow [/latex]Realization is possible. (B) [latex]\frac{G_{1}(s)}{G_{2}(s)} \Rightarrow[/latex] Realization is not possible because the gain of blocks given as [latex]G_{1}(s) [/latex] and [latex]G_{2}(s) [/latex] (C) [latex]G_{1}(s)\left(\frac{1}{G_{1}(s)}+G_{2}(s)\right)=1+G_{1}(s) G_{2}(s) [/latex] Realization is possible. (D) [latex]G_{1}(s)\left(\frac{1}{G_{1}(s)}-G_{2}(s)\right)=1-G_{1}(s) G_{2}(s) [/latex] Realization is possible.

question: Question 80 A plant transfer function is given as [latex]G(s)=(K_{P}+\frac{K_{I}}{s})\frac{1}{s(s+2)}[/latex]. When the plant operates in a unity feedback configuration, the condition for the stability of the closed loop system is
solution: [latex]G(s)=\left(K_{p}+\frac{K_{I}}{s}\right)\left(\frac{1}{s(s+2)}\right)[/latex] The closed loop transfer function for unity feedback [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{G(s)}{1+G(s)} &=\frac{\left(K_{p} s+K_{I}\right)}{s^{2}(s+2)+\left(K_{p} s+K_{I}\right)} \\ &=\frac{K_{p} s+K_{I}}{s^{3}+2 s^{2}+K_{p} s+K_{I}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Using Routh's tabular form: [latex] \begin{array}{c|cc} s^{3} & 1 & K_{p} \\ s^{2} & 2 & K_{I} \\ s^{1} & \frac{2 K_{p}-K_{I}}{2} & 0 \\ s^{0} & K_{p} & \end{array}[/latex] For system to be stable; [latex] \begin{aligned} K_{p}& \gt 0\\ \text{and }\frac{2 K_{p}-K_{I}}{2}& \gt 0 \\ \text{or} \quad 2 K_{p}-K_{I}& \gt 0 \\ \text{or} \quad K_{p}& \gt \frac{K_{I}}{2} \gt 0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 81 A lead compensator network includes a parallel combination of R and C in the feed-forward path. If the transfer function of the compensator is [latex]G(s)=\frac{s+2}{s+4}[/latex] , the value of RC is ________.
solution: [latex]G_{C}(s)=\frac{s+2}{s+4} \quad\dots(i)[/latex] For lead compensator, Transfer function [latex]=\frac{1+s \tau}{1+\alpha s \tau} \quad\dots(ii)[/latex] Where, [latex] \tau=[/latex] Lead time constant [latex]=R_{1} C [/latex] and [latex]\alpha=\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}} [/latex] Comparing equation (i) and (ii), we get [latex] \tau=\frac{1}{2} \quad [/latex] and [latex]\quad \alpha \tau=\frac{1}{4} [/latex] or, [latex]\alpha=\frac{1}{2} [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] RC time constant =0.5

question: Question 82 The open-loop transfer function of a plant in a unity feedback configuration is given as [latex]G(s)=\frac{K(s+4)}{(s+8)(s^{2}-9)}[/latex] . The value of the gain K(> 0) for which -1+ j2 lies on the root locus is_______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G(s) &=\frac{K(s+4)}{(s+8)\left(s^{2}-9\right)} \\ &=\frac{K(s+4)}{(s+8)(s+3)(s-3)} \end{aligned}[/latex] For the point (-1+2 j) to lie on the root locus the angle condition must be satisfy i.e. [latex]\angle G(s) H(s)=\pm(2 Q+1) 180^{\circ} [/latex] Taking LHS: [latex] \begin{array}{l} \left.\angle G(s) H(s)\right|_{s=-1+2 j} \\ =\frac{\angle K+\angle(s+4)}{\angle(s+8)+\angle(s+3)+\angle(s-3)} \\ =\frac{\angle K+\angle(-1+2 j+4)}{\angle(-1+2 j+8)+\angle(-1+2 j+3)+\angle(-1+2 j-3)} \\ =\frac{0+\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)}{\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{2}{7}\right)+\tan ^{-1}(1)+180^{\circ}-\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)} \\ =33.69^{\circ}-15.945^{\circ}-45^{\circ}-180^{\circ}+26.565^{\circ} \\ \simeq 180^{\circ} \end{array}[/latex] As angle condition is satisfied the value of system gain K can be obtained by using magnitude condition [latex] \begin{array}{l} i.e. |G(s) H(s)|_{s=-1+2 j}=1 \\ =\frac{K \sqrt{(-1+4)^{2}+2^{2}}}{\sqrt{(-1+8)^{2}+2^{2}} \cdot \sqrt{(-1+3)^{2}+2^{2}} \cdot \sqrt{(-1-3)^{2}+2^{2}}} \\ =1 \\ =\frac{K \sqrt{9+4}}{\sqrt{49+4} \sqrt{4+4} \sqrt{16+4}}=1 \\ =\frac{K \sqrt{13}}{\sqrt{53} \sqrt{8} \sqrt{20}}=1 \\ K=\frac{\sqrt{53 \times 8 \times 20}}{\sqrt{13}}=25.54 \end{array}[/latex]

[latex]G(s)=\frac{10(s+1)}{(s+10)}[/latex] For [latex]\omega=0 \Rightarrow M_{1}=1[/latex] and [latex]\phi_{1}=0^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] \omega=0 \Rightarrow M_{2}=10 [/latex] and [latex]\phi_{2}=-\tan ^{-1} \infty+\tan ^{-1} \infty=0^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] Polar plot As the zero is nearer to the imaginary axis hence
the direction of polar plot is clockwise.

question: Question 84 A unity negative feedback system has the open-loop transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+1)(s+3)}[/latex]. The value of the gain K ([latex]\gt[/latex]0) at which the root locus crosses the imaginary axis is ________.
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+1)(s+3)}[/latex] The characteristic equation [latex] \begin{array}{l} =1+G(s) H(s)=0 \\ =s(s+1)(s+3)+K=0 \\ =s^{3}+4 s^{2}+3 s+K=0 \end{array}[/latex] Using Routh's tabular form [latex] \begin{array}{c|cc} s^{3} & 1 & 3 \\ s^{2} & 4 & K \\ s^{1} & \frac{12-K}{4} & 0 \\ s^{0} & K & \end{array}[/latex] In order to cross the imaginary axis, system should be marginally stable [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{12-K}{4}&=0\\ \text{or }\quad K&=12 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 86 The characteristic equation of a unity negative feedback system is [latex]1 + KG(s) = 0[/latex]. The open loop transfer function G(s) has one pole at 0 and two poles at -1. The root locus of the system for varying K is shown in the figure. The constant damping ratio line  for [latex]\xi= 0.5[/latex], intersects the root locus at point A. The distance from the origin to point A is given as 0.5. The value of K at point A is ____.
solution: According to the question [latex] G(s) H(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+1)^{2}} \qquad \ldots(i)[/latex] The damping ratio is given as [latex]\xi=0.5[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \theta=\cos ^{-1} \xi=60^{\circ}[/latex] Let the co-ordinates of point 'A' is (-a+jb) where, [latex]\cos 60^{\circ}=\frac{O B}{O A} \qquad \ldots(ii)[/latex] Also, [latex]\quad O A=0.5 [/latex] (Given) [latex] \therefore O B=0.25[/latex] Similarly, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \sin 60^{\circ}=\frac{B A}{O A} \qquad \ldots(iii)\\ \therefore \quad B A=j b=0.433 j \end{array}[/latex] Hence, co-ordinates of [latex]A = -0.25 + 0.43j[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] The value of system gain K can be obtained as [latex] |G(s) H(s)|=1\qquad \ldots(iv)[/latex] From (i) and (iv) we get [latex]s=-0.25+j 4.33 [/latex] [latex] K=0.37[/latex]

question: Question 87 Consider a transfer function [latex]G_{p}(s)=\frac{ps^{2}+3ps-2}{s^{2}+(3+p)s+(2-p)}[/latex] with [latex]p[/latex] a positive real parameter. The maximum value of [latex]p[/latex] until which [latex]G_{p}[/latex] remains stable is ____.
solution: Given transfer function [latex] G_{p}(s)=\frac{p s^{2}+3 p s-2}{s^{2}+(3+p) s+(2-p)} \qquad\ldots(i)[/latex] The characteristic equation is [latex] =s^{2}+(3+p) s+(2-p)\qquad\ldots(ii)[/latex] Using Routh Hurtwiz criterion, [latex] \begin{array}{l|ll} s^{2} & 1 & (2-P) \\ s^{1} & (3+p) & 0 \\ s^{0} & (2-p) & 0 \end{array}[/latex] For system to be remain stable [latex] \begin{aligned} 2-p & \geq 0 \\ p_{\max } &=1.99 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 88 The state transition matrix [latex]\phi (t)[/latex] of a system [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \dot{x}_{1}\\ \dot{x}_{2} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1\\ 0&0 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}\\ x_{2} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given } &\left[\begin{array}{l} \dot{x}_{1} \\ \dot{x}_{2} \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{ll} 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l} x_{1} \\ x_{2} \end{array}\right] \\ A &=\left[\begin{array}{ll} 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{array}\right] \\ [s I-A] &=\left[\begin{array}{ll} s & 0 \\ 0 & s \end{array}\right]-\left[\begin{array}{ll} 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{ll} s & -1 \\ 0 & s \end{array}\right] \\ [s I-A]=s^{2} & \\ \phi(t) &=\mathcal{L}^{-1}[s I-A]^{-1} \\ &=\frac{1}{s^{2}}\left[\begin{array}{ll} s & 1 \\ 0 & s \end{array}\right] \\ &=L^{-1}\left[\begin{array}{cc} \frac{1}{s} & \frac{1}{s^{2}} \\ 0 & \frac{1}{s} \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{ll} 1 & t \\ 0 & 1 \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 89 For the second order closed-loop system shown in the figure, the natural frequency (in rad/s) is
solution: The closed loop transfer function of the given system is [latex] \frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{4}{s(s+4)+4}=\frac{4}{s^{2}+4 s+4} [/latex] Comparing with standard second order transfer [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{function }\quad &\frac{K \omega_{n}^{2}}{S^{2}+2 \xi \omega_{n}+\omega_{n}^{2}} \\ \text{we get, }\quad \omega_{n}^{2}&=4 \\ \text{or }\quad\omega_{n}&=\sqrt{4}=2 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 90 In a Bode magnitude plot, which one of the following slopes would be exhibited at high frequencies by a [latex]4^{th}[/latex] order all-pole system ?
solution:
A [latex]4^{\text {th }}[/latex]  order all-pole system means that the system

and [latex]s^{4}[/latex]  terms in denominator or 4 -poles. i.e.  [latex]H(s) \propto \frac{1}{s^{4}} [/latex] One pole exhibits -20 dB/decade slope, so 4 pole

question: Question 92 The state equation of a second-order linear system is given by [latex]\dot{x}(t) = Ax(t), \;\; x(0) = x_{0}[/latex] For  [latex]x_{0}=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1 \end{bmatrix}, \; x(t)=\begin{bmatrix} e^{-t}\\ -e^{-t} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] and  for [latex] x_{0}=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix},[/latex] [latex] x(t)=\begin{bmatrix} e^{-t}-e^{-2t}\\ -e^{-t}+2e^{-2t} \end{bmatrix} [/latex] when  [latex] x_{0}=\begin{bmatrix} 3\\ 5 \end{bmatrix}[/latex], x(t) is
solution: Given [latex]\dot{x}(t)=A x(t), \quad x(0)=x_{0} [/latex] Taking the Laplace transform [latex] \begin{aligned} s X(s)-x(0) &=A X(s) \\ [s I-A] X(s) &=x(0) \\ X(s) &=[s I-A]^{-1} x(0) \\ x(t) &=\mathcal{L}^{-1}[s I-A]^{-1} x(0) &\ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] Condition given are [latex] \begin{aligned} For x_{0}&=\left[\begin{array}{c}1 \\ -1\end{array}\right], x(t)=\left[\begin{array}{c}e^{-t} \\ -e^{-t}\end{array}\right] \\ For x_{0}&=\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right], x(t)=\left[\begin{array}{l}e^{-t}-e^{-2 t} \\ -e^{-t}+2 e^{-2 t}\end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] Using the linearity property in equation (i) [latex] K_{1} x_{1}(t)=\mathcal{L}^{-1}[s I-A]^{-1} x_{1}(0) K_{1} [/latex] [latex] K_{2} x_{2}(t)=\mathcal{L}^{-1}[s I-A]^{-1} x_{2}(0) K_{2} [/latex] Using the linearity property as [latex] \begin{aligned} K_{1} x_{1}(t)+K_{2} x_{2}(t)&=\mathcal{L}^{-1}[s I-A]^{-1} \\  \left[K_{1} x_{1}(0)+K_{2} x_{2}(0)\right] & \quad \ldots(ii)\\ \text { Also } \quad X_{3}(s)&=[s I-A]^{-1} x_{3}(0) \\ \text{So, } \quad K_{1}\left[\begin{array}{r}1 \\ -1\end{array}\right]+&K_{2}\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l}3 \\ 5\end{array}\right] \\ \left[\begin{array}{l}K_{1}+O K_{2} \\ -K_{1}+K_{2}\end{array}\right]&=\left[\begin{array}{l}3 \\ 5\end{array}\right] \\ \Rightarrow \quad K_{1}&=3 \\ K_{2}&=8 \end{aligned}[/latex] So, from equation (ii), we get x(t) [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t) &=K_{1} x_{1}(t)+K_{2} x_{2}(t) \\ &=3\left[\begin{array}{c} e^{-t} \\ -e^{-t} \end{array}\right]+8\left[\begin{array}{c} e^{-t}-e^{-2 t} \\ -e^{-t}+2 e^{-2 t} \end{array}\right] \\ &=\left[\begin{array}{c} 11 e^{-t}-8 e^{-2 t} \\ -1 t e^{-t}+16 e^{-2 t} \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 96 The Bode asymptotic magnitude plot of a minimum phase system is shown in
the figure If the system is connected in a unity negative feedback configuration, the steady state error of the closed loop system, to a unit ramp input, is_____.
solution: The open loop transfer function of the system [latex] G(s) H(s)=\frac{K\left(\frac{s}{2}+1\right)}{s\left(\frac{s}{10}+1\right)}\qquad\ldots(i)[/latex] where, [latex] \left.26.02\right|_{\omega=0.1}=20 \log K-20 \log \omega\qquad\ldots(ii)[/latex] Or, [latex]\quad K=1.99 \simeq 2[/latex] From equation (i) and (ii), we get [latex] G(s)=\frac{20(s+2)}{2 s(s+10)}\qquad\ldots(iii)[/latex] Steady state error for ramp input is [latex] e_{s s}=\frac{A}{K_{V}} \text { where } K_{V}=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s G(s)[/latex] From equation (iii), [latex] K_{V}=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s \times \frac{10(s+2)}{s(s+10)}=2[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad e_{s s}=\frac{1}{2}=0.5[/latex]

question: Question 97 An unforced linear time invariant (LTI) system is represented by [latex]\begin{vmatrix} \dot{x}_{1}\\ \dot{x}_{2} \end{vmatrix}=\begin{vmatrix} -1 & 0\\ 0&-2 \end{vmatrix}\begin{vmatrix} x_{1}\\ x_{2} \end{vmatrix}[/latex] If the initial conditions are [latex]x_{1}(0)=1 \; and \; x_{2}(0)=-1[/latex], the solution of the state equation is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}\left[\begin{array}{l}\dot{x}_{1} \\ \dot{x}_{2}\end{array}\right] &=\left[\begin{array}{cc}-1 & 0 \\ 0 & -2\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}x_{1} \\ x_{2}\end{array}\right] \\ \dot{x}_{1} &=-x_{1}+0 x_{2} \\ \dot{x}_{2} &=0 x_{1}-2 x_{2} \end{aligned} [/latex] Applying Laplace transform on both equations [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow s X_{1}(s)-x_{1}(0)&=-X_{1}(s) \\ X_{1}(s)[s+1]&=X_{1}(0) \quad &\text{given }x_{1}(0)=1 \\ X_{1}(s)&=\frac{1}{s+1} \\ \Rightarrow \quad e^{-t}&=x_{1}(t)\\ \Rightarrow \quad s X_{2}(s)-X_{2}(0)&=-2 X_{2}(s) \\ (s+2) X_{2}(s)&=X_{2}(0) &X_{2}(0)=-1 \\ X_{2}(s)&=-\frac{1}{s+2} \\ x_{2}(t)&=-e^{-2 t} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 98 For the following system, when [latex]X_{1}(s) = 0[/latex], the transfer function [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{X_{2}(s)}[/latex]  is
solution: Redrawing the block diagram with [latex]X_{1}(s)=0 [/latex] The transfer function [latex] T(s)=\frac{Y(s)}{X_{2}(s)}=\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s) H(s)} \quad\ldots(i)[/latex] Here, [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{s}[/latex] and [latex]H(s)=\frac{s}{s+1} [/latex] [latex] \frac{Y(s)}{X_{2}(s)}=\frac{1 / s}{1+\frac{1}{s} \times \frac{s}{s+1}}=\frac{(s+1)}{s(s+2)}[/latex]

question:
Question 99 The natural frequency of an undamped second-order system is 40 rad/s. If the
system is damped with a damping ratio 0.3, the damped natural frequency in
rad/s is ______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given, } & \omega_{n}=40 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \\ & \xi=0.3 \\ \therefore \quad & \omega_{d}=\omega_{n} \sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}=38.16 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 100 For the following feedback system [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{(s+1)(s+2)}[/latex]. The 2% settling time of the step response is required to be less than 2 seconds.
Which one of the following compensators C(s) achieves this ?
solution: Given open loop transfer function is [latex] \begin{aligned} G(s)&=\frac{1}{(s+1)(s+2)} \\ \therefore T(s)&=\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s)}=\frac{1}{(s+1)(s+2)+1} \\ T(s)&=\frac{1}{s^{2}+3 s+3} &\ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] Comparing equation (i) with standard transfer function [latex] \xi \omega_{n}=\frac{3}{2}=1.5 [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] 2% settling time [latex] \tau_{s}=\frac{4}{\xi \omega_{n}}=\frac{4}{1.5}=2.67>2 \mathrm{sec} [/latex] Thus, in order to make settling time [latex]\left(\tau_{s}\right)[/latex] less than 2 sec, PD controller should be used. Hence, option (C) is the correct choice. Where, [latex]C(s)=2(s+4) [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] New transfer function [latex]=T^{\prime}(G)[/latex] [latex] =\frac{C(s) G(s)}{1+C(s) G(s)}=\frac{2(s+4)}{s^{2}+3 s+2+2 s+8} [/latex] or [latex]T^{\prime}(s)=\frac{2(s+4)}{s^{2}+5 s+10}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \tau_{s}=\frac{4}{\xi \omega_{n}}=\frac{4}{5 / 2}=\frac{4}{2.5}=1.6[/latex]

question:
Question 101 The phase margin in degrees of [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{(s+0.1)(s+1)(s+10)}[/latex]
 calculated using the asymptotic Bode plot is _____.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \frac{10}{0.7 \times 10\left(\frac{s}{0.1}+1\right)\left(\frac{s}{1}+1\right)\left(\frac{s}{10}+1\right)} \\ =\frac{10}{\left(\frac{s}{0.1}+1\right)\left(\frac{s}{1}+1\right)\left(\frac{s}{10}+1\right)} \\ \text { Amount of shitt }=2010 \mathrm{g} \mathrm{K}=20 \mathrm{log} 10=20 \mathrm{dB} \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} -20dB&=\frac{20-0}{\log0.1-\log\omega_{gc}}\\ \text{or},\omega_{gc}&=1\mathrm{rad}/\mathrm{sec}&\ldots(i)\\ \mathrm{PM}&=180^{\circ}+\angle GH(j\omega|_{at\omega=\omega_{wc}}&\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] From the given transfer function, [latex] \begin{aligned} \angle G(j \omega)&=-\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\omega_{g c}}{0.1}\right)-\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\omega_{g c}}{1}\right) \\ &-\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\omega_{g c}}{10}\right) \\ \alpha \angle G(j(1)) &=-84.289^{\circ}-45^{\circ}-5.711^{\circ} \\ &=-135^{\circ} &\ldots(iii) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] From equation(ii) and (iii) we get, [latex] \text { Phase margin } \mathrm{PM}=180^{\circ}-135^{\circ}=45^{\circ}[/latex]

question: Question 102 Consider the state space model of a system, as given below [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \dot{x}_{1}\\ \dot{x}_{2}\\ \dot{x}_{3} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{vmatrix} -1 & 1&0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0\\ 0&0 & -2 \end{vmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}\\ x_{2}\\ x_{3} \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 4\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}u;y\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 &1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}\\ x_{2}\\ x_{3} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{c}\dot{x}_{1} \\ \dot{x}_{2} \\ \dot{x}_{3}\end{array}\right]&=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}-1 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -2\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}x_{1} \\ x_{2} \\ x_{3}\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 4 \\ 0\end{array}\right] u \\ y&=[1 \;1 \;1 ]\left[\begin{array}{r}x_{3} \\ x_{3} \\ x_{3}\end{array}\right] \\ A&=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}-1 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -2\end{array}\right], B=\left[\begin{array}{l}x_{1} \\ x_{2} \\ 0\end{array}\right], C=\left[1\;1\;1\right] \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Check for controllability: [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{C} &=\left[B: A B: A^{2} B\right] \\ &=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 & 4 & -8 \\ 4 & -4 & 4 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] For controllable. [latex] \left|Q_{c}\right| \neq 0[/latex] Here , [latex]\quad\left|Q_{c}\right|=4(0)=0 \quad \therefore[/latex] Uncontrollable Check for observability: [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{0} &=\left[C^{T}: A^{T} C^{T}: A^{2 T} C^{T}\right] \\ &=\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 & -1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & -1 \\ 1 & -2 & 4 \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] For observable, [latex] \left|Q_{0}\right| \neq 0[/latex] Here, [latex]\left|Q_{o}\right|=1 \quad \therefore [/latex] Observable

question:
Question 104 The forward path transfer function of a unity negative feedback system is given
 by [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{(s+2)(s-1)}[/latex] The value of K which will place both the poles of the closed-loop system at the same location, is ______.
solution: Given that, [latex]\quad G(s)=\frac{K}{(s+2)(s-1)} [/latex] Using root locus method, the break point can be obtain as [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad 1+G(s)&=0 \\ 1+\frac{K}{(s+2)(s-1)} &=0 \\ \text{or }\quad K&=-(s+2)(s-1)\\ \frac{d K}{d s} &=-2 s-1=0 \\ \text{or }\quad s &=-0.5 \end{aligned}[/latex] To have, both the poles at the same directions [latex] \begin{aligned} |G(s)|_{s=0.5} &=1 \\ K &=2.25 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 105 The state diagram of a system is shown below. A system is described by the state-variable equations [latex]\dot{X}= AX+Bu[/latex] ; [latex]y=CX+Du[/latex] The state transition matrix [latex]e^{At}[/latex] of the system shown in the figure above is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A &=\left[\begin{array}{rr} -1 & 0 \\ 1 & -1 \end{array}\right] \\ s I-A&=\left[\begin{array}{cc} s+1 & 0 \\ -1 & s+1 \end{array}\right] \\ [s I-A]^{-1}&=\frac{1}{(s+1) \times(s+1)}\left[\begin{array}{cc} s+1 & 0 \\ 1 & s+1 \end{array}\right]\\ [s I-A]^{-1}&=\left[\begin{array}{cc}\frac{1}{s+1} & 0 \\ \frac{1}{(s+1)^{2}} & \frac{1}{s+1}\end{array}\right] \\ \phi(t)&=e^{A t}=L^{-1}\left\{(s I-A)^{-1}\right\} \\ e^{A t}&=\left[\begin{array}{cc}e^{-t} & 0 \\ t e^{-t} & e^{-t}\end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 106 The state diagram of a system is shown below. A system is described by the state-variable equations [latex]\dot{X}= AX+Bu[/latex];  [latex]y=CX+Du[/latex] The state-variable equations of the system shown in the figure above are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{So}, \dot{x}_{1} &=-x_{1}-u \\ \dot{x}_{2} &=-\left(x_{2}+\dot{x}_{1}\right)=-\left(x_{2}-x_{1}-u\right) \\ \dot{x}_{2} &=x_{1}-x_{2}+u \\ y &=\dot{x}_{2} \\ y &=x_{1}-x_{2}+u \\ \dot{x}_{2} &=\left[\begin{array}{rr}-1 & 0 \\1 & -1\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} x_{1} \\x_{2}\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{c}-1 \\1 \end{array}\right] u \\ \dot{x} &=\left[\begin{array}{rr} -1 & 0 \\ 1 & -1 \end{array}\right] X+\left[\begin{array}{c} -1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] u \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 107 The signal flow graph for a system is given below. The transfer function [latex]\frac{Y\left ( s \right )}{U\left ( s \right )}[/latex] for this system is
solution: Using Mason's gain formula, [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta &=1-\left[-2 s^{-1}-2 s^{-2}-4-4 s^{-1}\right] \\ \Delta &=1+\frac{2}{s}+\frac{2}{s^{2}}+4+\frac{4}{s} \\ \Delta &=\frac{5 s^{2}+6 s+2}{s^{2}} \\ P_{1} &=s^{2}=\frac{1}{s^{2}} \\ P_{2} &=s^{-1}=\frac{1}{s} \\ \Delta_{1} &=1 \\ \Delta_{2} &=1 \\ \frac{Y(s)}{U(s)} &=\frac{\sum P_{k} \Delta_{k}}{\Delta}=\frac{\frac{1}{s^{2}} \times 1+\frac{1}{s} \times 1}{\frac{5 s^{2}+6 s+2}{s^{2}}} \\ \frac{Y(s)}{U(s)} &=\frac{s+1}{5 s^{2}+6 s+2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 108 A system described by a linear, constant coefficient, ordinary, first order differential equation has an exact solution given by y(t) for t > 0, when the forcing function is x(t) and the initial condition is y(0). If one wishes to modify the system so that the solution becomes -2y(t) for t > 0, we need to
solution: [latex]\frac{d y(t)}{d t}+k y(t)=x(t) [/latex] Taking Laplace transform of both sides, we have [latex] s Y(s)-y(0)+k Y(s)=X(s) [/latex] [latex] Y(s)[s+k]=X(s)+y(0) [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow Y(s)=\frac{X(s)}{s+k}+\frac{y(0)}{s+k} [/latex] Taking inverse Laplace transform, we have [latex] y(t)=e^{-k t} x(t)+y(0) e^{-k t} [/latex] So if we want -2y(t) as a solution both x(t) and  y(0) has to be multiplied by -2; hence change x(t) by -2x(t) and y(0) by -2y(0).

options.A: change the initial condition to -y(0) and the forcing function to 2x(t)
options.B: change the initial condition to 2y(0) and the forcing function to -x(t)
options.C: change the initial condition to [latex]j\sqrt{2}y\left ( 0 \right )[/latex] and the forcing function to [latex]j\sqrt{2}x\left ( t \right )[/latex]
options.D: change the initial condition to -2y(0) and the forcing function to -2x(t)

question: Question 109 The open-loop transfer function of a dc motor is given as [latex]\frac{w\left ( s \right )}{V_{a}\left ( s \right )}= \frac{10}{1+10s}[/latex]. When connected in feedback as shown below, the approximate value of [latex]K_{a}[/latex] that will reduce the time constant of the closed loop system by one hundred times as compared to that of the open-loop system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{\omega(s)}{V_{a}(s)} &=\frac{10}{1+10 s} \\ 1+T s &=1+10 s \\ T s &=10 s \\ \therefore \quad T &=10\\ T^{\prime}=& \frac{T}{100}=\frac{10}{100}=\frac{1}{10} \\ \frac{\omega(s)}{R(s)}=& \frac{K_{a} \times \frac{10}{1+10 s}}{1+K_{a} \frac{10}{1+10 s}} \\ \frac{\omega(s)}{R(s)}&=\frac{10 K_{a}}{1+10 s+10 K_{a}}=\frac{10 K_{a}}{\left(1+10 K_{a}\right)+10s} \\ \frac{\omega(s)}{R(s)}&=\frac{10k_{a}}{\left(1+10 K_{a}\right)\left[1+\frac{10 s}{1+10 K_{a}}\right]} \\ T^{\prime}&=\frac{10}{1+10K_{a}}=\frac{1}{10}\\ 1+10 K_{a}&=100 \\ 10 K_{a}&=99 \\ K_{a}&=9.9 \\ K_{a} &\cong 10 \end{aligned}[/latex]

The gain [latex]\left ( 20\log\left | G\left ( s \right ) \right | \right )[/latex] is 32 dB and -8 dB at 1 rad/s and 10 rad/s respectively. The phase is negative for all [latex]\omega[/latex]. Then G(s) is
solution: [latex]10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] to [latex]1 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] is 1 decade [latex] 32-(-8)=40 d B [/latex] So, the slope is 40dB/decade it means there are two poles at origin, it means either option (B) or  option (D) is correct put [latex]\omega=1[/latex]rad/sec in both the options. [latex] 20 \log \left[\frac{39.8}{(1)^{2}}\right]=32 \mathrm{dB} [/latex] [latex] 20 \log \left[\frac{32}{(1)^{2}}\right]=30.1 \mathrm{dB} [/latex] So, option (B) is correct option [latex]=\frac{39.8}{s^{2}}[/latex]

question: Question 111 The transfer function of a compensator is given as [latex]G_{c}(s)=\frac{s+a}{s+b}[/latex] The phase of the above lead compensator is maximum at
solution: For phase to be maximum, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial P}{\partial \omega}&=0 \\ \frac{1}{1+\frac{\omega^{2}}{a^{2}}}- \frac{1/b}{1+\frac{\omega^{2}}{b^{2}}}&=0 \\ \frac{1}{1+\omega^{2}}- \frac{1/b}{1+\frac{\omega^{2}}{4}}&=0\\ \frac{1}{1+\omega^{2}}-\frac{2}{\omega^{2}+4} &=0 \\ \omega^{2}+4-2-2 \omega^{2} &=0 \\ \omega^{2} &=2 \\ \omega &=\sqrt{2} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 112 The transfer function of a compensator is given as [latex]G_{c}(s)=\frac{s+a}{s+b}[/latex] [latex]G_{c}(S)[/latex] is a lead compensator if
solution: [latex]G_{c}(s)=\left(\frac{s+a}{s+b}\right)[/latex] Phase [latex]P=\tan ^{-1}(\omega / a)-\tan ^{-1} \omega / b [/latex] for lead comparators phase must be + ve. for this [latex]\frac{\omega}{a} \gt \frac{\omega}{b} \Rightarrow a \lt b [/latex] So [latex]a=1, b=2[/latex]

The system is controllable for
Question 114 The feedback system shown below oscillates at 2 rad/s when
solution: Characteristic equation is [latex] 1+G(s)H(s)=0[/latex] [latex] 1+\frac{K(s+1)}{s^{3}+a s^{2}+2 s+1}=0 [/latex] [latex] s^{3}+a s^{2}+(2+K) s+(1+K)=0 [/latex] array for this is Routh [latex] \begin{array}{l|lr} s^{3} & 1 & (2+K) \\ s^{2} & a & (1+K) \\ s^{1} & \frac{a(2+K)-(1+K)}{a} \\ s^{0} & (1+K) & \end{array}[/latex] For oscillation [latex]\frac{a(2+K)-(1+K)}{a}=0 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad a=\left(\frac{1+K}{2+K}\right) [/latex] Now [latex] \begin{aligned} a s^{2}+(1+K)&=0 \\ -a \omega^{2}+(1+K)&=0 \\ \text{given }\quad \omega&=2 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \\ -4 a+(1+K)&=0 \\ -4 \frac{(1+K)}{(2+K)}+(1+K)&=0 \\ -4(1+K)+(2+K)(1+K)&=0 \\ (1+K)[(2+K)-4]&=0 \\ K=-1,2 \end{aligned}[/latex] but K=-1 is not possible as system will not  oscillate for this as a=0 So, K=2 [latex] a=\frac{1+K}{2+K}=\frac{3}{4}=0.75[/latex]

question: Question 115 A system with transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{(s^{2}+9)(s+2)}{(s+1)(s+3)(s+4)}[/latex] is excited by sin([latex]\omega[/latex] t). The steady-state output of the system is zero at
solution: Transfer function is [latex] \begin{aligned} G(s)&=\frac{\left(s^{2}+9\right)(s+2)}{(s+1)(s+3)(s+4)} \\ \text{Input }\quad X(s)&=L \cdot T[\sin \omega t]\\ X(s)&=\frac{\omega}{s^{2}+\omega^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex] So output [latex] Y(s)=\frac{\left(s^{2}+9\right)(s+2)}{(s+1)(s+3)(s+4)} \cdot \frac{\omega}{\left(s^{2}+\omega^{2}\right)}[/latex] Now [latex] \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} y(t)=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} S Y(s)=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s \frac{\left(s^{2}+9\right)(s+2)}{(s+1)(s+3)(s+4)} \cdot \frac{\omega}{\left(s^{2}+\omega^{2}\right)}[/latex] this will be zero if [latex] s^{2}+\omega^{2}[/latex] will cancel [latex]\left(s^{2}+9\right)[/latex] term as only then final value theorem will be applicable. So at [latex]\omega^{2}=9 \Rightarrow \omega=3 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec},[/latex] steady state output will be zero.
