question:
Question 117 The input-output transfer function of a plant [latex]H(s)=\frac{100}{s(s+10)^2}[/latex].
The plant is
placed in a unity negative feedback configuration as shown in the figure below. The gain margin of the system under closed loop unity negative feedback is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G(s) H(s) &=\frac{100}{s(s+10)^{2}} \\ \phi &=-90^{\circ}-2 \tan ^{-1}(\omega / 10) \end{aligned}[/latex] For phase cross-over frequency, [latex]\phi=-180^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad-180 &=-90^{\circ}-2 \tan ^{-1}(\omega / 10) \\ \Rightarrow & \omega=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \\ s &=j \omega \\ \text { Put, } \quad G(j \omega) H(j \omega) &=\frac{100}{j \omega(j \omega+100)^{2}} \\ |G(j \omega) H(j \omega)|_{\omega=10} &=\frac{100}{\omega\left(\omega^{2}+100\right)} \\ &=\frac{100}{10(200)}=\frac{1}{20} \\ \text { G.M. } &=\frac{1}{\mid G(j \omega) H(j \omega)}=20 \end{aligned} [/latex] G.M. in [latex]\mathrm{dB}=20 \log 20=26 \mathrm{dB}[/latex]

question:
Question 118 The block diagram of a system with one input it and two outputs [latex]y_1 \; and \; y_2[/latex] is
given below. A state space model of the above system in terms of the state vector [latex]\underline{x}[/latex] and the output vector [latex]\underline{y}= [y_{1}    \; y_{2}]^{T}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{Y_{1}(s)}{U(s)} &=\frac{1}{s+2} \\ \frac{Y_{2}(s)}{U(s)} &=\frac{2}{s+2} \\ \frac{Y_{1}(s)}{x_{1}(s)} \frac{x_{1}(s)}{U(s)} &=\frac{1}{s+2} \\ \frac{r_{2}(s)}{x_{2}(s)} \frac{x_{2}(s)}{U(s)} &=\frac{2}{s+2} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{X_{1}(s)}{U(s)} &=\frac{1}{s+2} \text { and } \frac{Y_{1}(s)}{X_{1}(s)}=1 \\ \frac{x_{2}(s)}{U(s)} &=\frac{1}{s+2} \text { and } \frac{Y_{2}(s)}{U(s)}=2 \\ s X_{1}(s)+2 X_{1}(s) &=U(s) \\ \text{and} \quad Y_{1}(s) &=x_{1}(s) \\ s X_{2}(s)+2 X_{2}(s) &=U(s) \\ \text{and }\quad Y_{2}(s)&=2 X_{2}(s) \\ \dot{x}_{1}(t)+2 x_{1}(t)&=U(t) \\ \text{and }y_{1}(t)&=x_{1}(t) \\ \dot{x}_{2}(t)+2 x_{2}(t)&=U(t) \\ y_{2}(t)&=2 x_{2}(t) \end{aligned} [/latex] From Question, [latex]\begin{aligned} y &=\left[y_{1} y_{2}\right]^{\top}=[12]^{\top}=\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\2\end{array}\right] \\ \dot{x}_{1}(t) &=-2 x_{1}(t)+u(t) \\ \dot{x}_{2}(t) &=-2 x_{2}(t)+u(t) \\ \left[\begin{array}{c}\dot{x}_{1} \\\dot{x}_{2}\end{array}\right]&=\left[\begin{array}{cc}-2 & 0 \\-2 & 0\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}x_{1} \\x_{2} \end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\1\end{array}\right] u(t) \\ \dot{x} &=[-2] x+[1] u \end{aligned}[/latex] only option (B) is satisfied.

question:
Question 119 For the transfer function [latex]G(j\omega)=5+j\omega[/latex], the corresponding Nyquist plot for
positive frequency has the form

question: Question 120 The differential equation [latex]100\frac{d^{2}y}{dt^{2}}-20\frac{dy}{dt}+y=x(t)[/latex] describes a system with an in put x(t) and an output y(t). The system, which is initially relaxed, is excited by a unit step input. The output y(t) can be represented by the waveform
solution: [latex]100 \frac{d^{2} y}{d t^{2}}-20 \frac{d y}{d t}+y=x(t)[/latex] Taking Laplace transform of both sides [latex] 100 s^{2} Y(s)-20 s Y(s)+Y(s)=\frac{X(s)}{s}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}=\frac{1 / s}{\left(100 s^{2}-20 s+1\right)}=\frac{1}{s(10 s-1)^{2}} [/latex] Poles are at [latex]s=\frac{1}{10}, \frac{1}{10}, 0 [/latex] As poles are on the right-hand side of s-plane so given system is unstable system. Only option (A) represents unstable system.

question: Question 122 The signal flow graph of a system is shown below: The transfer function of the system is
solution: Forward path gain, [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{1} &=2\left(\frac{1}{s}\right)\left(\frac{1}{s}\right)(0.5)=\frac{1}{s^{2}} \\ P_{2} &=2\left(\frac{1}{s}\right)(1)(0.5)=\frac{1}{s} \\ \Delta_{1} &=1 \\ \Delta_{2} &=1 \\ \Delta &=1-\left\{-\frac{1}{s}-\frac{1}{s^{2}}\right\} \\ &=1+\frac{1}{s}+\frac{1}{s^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Transfer funct ion of the system, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{Y(s)}{U(s)} &=\frac{P_{1} \Delta_{1}+P_{2} \Delta_{2}}{\Delta} \\ &=-\frac{1}{1+\frac{s^{2}}{s}+\frac{1}{s}}=\frac{s+1}{s^{2}+s+1} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 124 A unity negative feedback closed loop system has a plant with the transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{s^{2}+2s+2}[/latex] and a controller [latex]G_{c}(s)[/latex] in the
feed forward path. For a unit set input, the transfer function of the controller that
gives minimum steady state error is
solution: Steady state error, [latex] \begin{aligned} e_{s s} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} \frac{s R(s)}{1+G(s) G_{c}(s)} \\ r(t) &=u(t) \\ R(s) &=\frac{1}{s} \\ e_{ss} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} \frac{s \cdot \frac{1}{s}}{1+G(s) G_{c}(s)} \\ e_{ss}&=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{1+G(s) G_{c}(s)} \\ \text { Taking, } \quad G_{c}(s) &=\frac{s+1}{s+2}, e_{s s}=\frac{2}{3} \\ \text { Taking, } \quad G_{c}(s) &=\frac{s+2}{s+1}, e_{s s}=\frac{1}{3} \\ \text { Taking, } \quad G_{c}(s) &=\frac{(s+1)(s+4)}{(s+2)(s+3)}, e_{s s}=\frac{3}{5} \\ \text { Taking, } \quad & G_{c}(s)=1+\frac{2}{s}+3 s, e_{s s}=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 126 A system with transfer function [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}=\frac{s}{s+p}[/latex] has an output [latex]y(t)=cos(2t-\frac{\pi }{3})[/latex] for the input signal [latex]x(t)=pcos(2t-\frac{\pi }{2})[/latex]. Then, the system parameter p is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \phi&=-\frac{\pi}{3}-\left(-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=\frac{\pi}{6}=30^{\circ}\\ \text{and }\quad\omega&=2 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] From the transfer function, [latex] \begin{aligned} \phi &=90^{\circ}-\tan ^{-1} \frac{\omega}{p} \\ 90^{\circ}-\tan ^{-1} \frac{2}{p} &=30^{\circ} \\ \tan ^{-1} \frac{2}{p} &=60^{\circ} \\ \frac{2}{p} &=\tan 60^{\circ}=\sqrt{3} \\ p &=\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 127 The transfer function Y(s)/R(s) of the system shown is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q(s) &=P(s)\left[\frac{1}{s+1}-\frac{1}{s+1}\right] \\ &=0 \\ \text{So,}\quad P(s) &=R(s)-0=R(s)\\ Y(s)&=\frac{P(s)}{s+1}=\frac{R(s)}{s+1}\\ \text{Therefore, }\quad\frac{Y(s)}{R(s)}&=\frac{1}{s+1} \end{aligned}\\[/latex]

question: Question 131 The feedback configuration and the pole-zero locations of [latex]G(s)=\frac{s^{2}-2s+2}{s^{2}+2s+2}[/latex] are shown below. The root locus for negative values of k , i.e. for [latex]-\infty \lt k \lt 0[/latex], has breakaway/break-in points and angle of departure at pole P (with respect to the positive real axis) equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} 1+G(s) H(s) &=0 \\ 1+\frac{K\left(s^{2}-2 s+2\right)}{s^{2}+2 s+2} &=0 \\ k &=-\frac{s^{2}+2 s+2}{s^{2}-2 s+2} \\ \text{put }\quad \frac{\partial K}{\partial s}&=0\text{ we have}\\ \left(s^{2}-2 s+2\right)(s+1) &-\left(s^{2}+2 s+2\right) \\ (s-1) =0 \\ 2 s^{2}-4 s^{2}+4 &=0 \\ 2 s^{2} &=+4 \\ s &=\pm \sqrt{2} \\ \text{Angle of departure is}\\ \phi_{D}=\phi\\ \text { where } &=\Sigma \phi_{2}-\Sigma \phi_{p} \\ &=225^{\circ} \\ \phi_{D} &=\pm 225^{\circ} \end{aligned} \\ \text{No option is matching.}[/latex]

question: Question 132 Consider the system [latex]\frac{dx}{dt}=Ax+Bu [/latex] with [latex]  A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 0&1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] and [latex] B=\begin{bmatrix} p\\ q \end{bmatrix}[/latex] where p and q are arbitrary real numbers. Which of the following statements about the controllability of the system is true ?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A&=\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 0 \\0 & 1\end{array}\right] \\ B&=\left[\begin{array}{l}p \\q\end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] For controllabil itycondition is [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{C}&=\left[B, A B, \ldots A^{n-1} B\right] \neq 0\\ A \cdot B&=\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 0 \\0 & 1\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}p \\q\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l}p+0 \\0+q\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l}p \\q\end{array}\right]\\ \text{So}\quad Q_{c}&=\left[\begin{array}{ll}p & p \\ q & q\end{array}\right]=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] So, the system is uncontrollable for all values of p and q

options.A: The system is completely state controllable for any nonzero values of p and q
options.B: Only p = 0 and q = 0 result in controllability
options.C: The system is uncontrollable for all values of p and q
options.D: We cannot conclude about controllability from the given data

Question 134 Group I gives two possible choices for the impedance Z in the diagram. The
circuit elements in Z satisfy the conditions [latex]R_{2}C_{2} \gt R_{1}C_{1}[/latex]. The transfer functions [latex]\frac{V_{o}}{V_{i}}[/latex] represents a kind of controller. Match the impedances in Group I with the type of controllers in Group II
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} \frac{V_{i}\left(R_{1} C_{1} S+1\right) 1}{R_{1}}=-\frac{V_{0}}{Z} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{V_{0}}{V_{i}}=-\frac{Z\left(R_{1} C_{1} S+1\right)}{R_{1}} \end{array}[/latex] In case of Q, [latex]\quad Z=\frac{R_{2} C_{2} s+1}{C_{2} S+1} [/latex] In case of R, [latex]\quad Z=\frac{R_{2}}{R_{2} C_{2} s+1} [/latex] Considering Q [latex] \frac{V_{0}}{V_{i}}=-\frac{\left(R_{1} C_{1} S+1\right)}{R_{1}} \cdot \frac{\left(R_{2} C_{2} S+1\right)}{C_{2} S}[/latex] Considering R , [latex] \frac{V_{0}}{V_{i}}=-\frac{\left(R_{1} C_{1} S+1\right)}{R_{1}} \cdot \frac{R_{2}}{\left(R_{2} C_{2} s+1\right)}[/latex] [latex] \because [/latex] Given that [latex]R_{2} C_{2}>R_{1} C_{1} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad [/latex] Considering R, controller is lag compensator. and Considering Q , Controller is PID controller.

question:
Question 135 The magnitude of frequency responses of an underdamped second order system
is 5 at 0 rad/sec and peaks to [latex]\frac{10}{\sqrt{3}}[/latex] at 5[latex]\sqrt{3}[/latex]
 rad/sec. The transfer function of the system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} M_{r}&=\frac{5}{2 \xi \sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}}=\frac{10}{\sqrt{3}} \\ \text{or}\quad\xi&=\frac{1}{2}\\ \text{Also, }\omega_{r}&=\omega_{n} \sqrt{1-2 z^{2}} \\ 5 \sqrt{2} &=\omega_{n} \sqrt{1-2 x\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)} \\ \text{or}\quad\omega_{n} &=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex] Only option (A) satisfies the conditions.

question: Question 136 The number of open right half plane of [latex]G(s)=\frac{10}{s^{5}+2s^{4}+3s^{3}+6s^{2}+5s+3}[/latex] is
solution: Characteristic equation [latex] q(s)=s^{5}+2 s^{4}+3 s^{3}+6 s^{2}+5 s+3 [/latex] Putting [latex]s=\frac{1}{z} [/latex] [latex] q^{\prime}(z)=3 z^{5}+5 z^{4}+6 z^{3}+3 z^{2}+2 z+1 [/latex] Routh array is [latex] \begin{array}{l|lll} z^{5} & 3 & 6 & 2 \\ z^{4} & 5 & 3 & 1 \\ z^{3} & 21 / 5 & 7 / 5 & \\ z^{2} & \frac{63}{51} =\frac{4}{3} & 1 &\\ z^{1} & \frac{\frac{28}{15}-\frac{21}{5}}{4 / 3} =\frac{-35 / 15}{4 / 3}=\frac{-7}{4} & &\\ z^{0} & 1 & & \end{array}[/latex] Sinc_e sign changes twice in Routh-array, therefore, there are two poles on right half plane.

solution: Comparing the given transfer functions with [latex] \begin{array}{c} \frac{\omega_{n}^{2}}{s^{2}+2 \xi \omega_{n} s+\omega_{n}^{2}} \\ P=\frac{25}{s^{2}+25} \Rightarrow \xi=0 \end{array}[/latex] So, P is undamped. question:
Question 140 A linear, time - invariant, causal continuous time system has a rational transfer
function with simple poles at s =- 2 and s =- 4 and one simple zero at s =- 1
. A unit step u(t) is applied at the input of the system. At steady state, the
output has constant value of 1. The impulse response of this system is
solution: Transfer functions can be written as, [latex] \begin{aligned} H(s)&=\frac{K(s+1)}{(s+2)(s+4)} \\ \text{Input,}\quad R(s)&=\frac{1}{s}\\ C(s)&=R(s) H(s) \\ \text{Given:} \quad \lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s C(s)&=1 \\ \text{or,} \quad\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} \frac{s \cdot K(s+1)}{s(s+2)(s+4)}&=1 \\ \text{Or }\quad \frac{K}{8}&=1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad K &=8 \\ H(s) &=\frac{8(s+1)}{(s+2)(s+4)} \\ &=-\frac{4}{s+2}+\frac{12}{s+4} \\ h(t) &=\left(-4 e^{-2 t}+12 e^{-4 t}\right) u(t) \end{aligned}[/latex] Which is also the required impulse response of the system.

To make [latex]M_{P}[/latex] same, [latex]\theta[/latex] should be the same.

question:
Question 145 The state space representation of a separately excited DC servo motor dynamics
is given as [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \frac{d\omega }{dt}\\ \frac{di_{a}}{dt} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} -1 & 1\\ -1&-10 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} \omega \\ i_{a} \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 10 \end{bmatrix}u[/latex] where [latex]\omega[/latex] is the speed of the motor, [latex]i_{a}[/latex] is the armature current and u is the armature voltage. The transfer function [latex]\frac{\omega (s)}{U(s)}[/latex] of the motor is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{c}\frac{d \omega}{d t} \\\frac{d i_{a}}{d t}\end{array}\right]&=\left[\begin{array}{cc} -1 & 1 \\ -1 & -10 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l} \omega \\ i_{a} \end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 10 \end{array}\right] u\\ \Rightarrow \frac{d \omega}{d t}&=-\omega+i_{\mathrm{a}} &\ldots(i)\\ \Rightarrow \frac{d i_{\mathrm{a}}}{d t}&=-\omega-10 i_{\mathrm{a}}+10 u &\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking Laplace transform (i) \& (ii) [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow s \omega(s)=-\omega(s)+I_{a}(s) \\ \Rightarrow(s+1) \omega(s)=I_{a}(s) \quad\ldots(iii)\\ \Rightarrow s I_{e}(s)=-\omega(s)-10 I_{a}(s)+10 U(s) \\ \Rightarrow \omega(s)=(-10-s) I_{a}(s)+10 U(s) \\ =(-10-s)(s+1) \omega(s)+10 U(s) \\ =-\left[s^{2}+11 s+10\right] \omega(s)+10 U(s) \\ \Rightarrow\left[s^{2}+11 s+11\right] \omega(s)=10 U(s) \\ \Rightarrow \frac{\omega(s)}{U(s)}=\frac{10}{\left(s^{2}+11 s+11\right)} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 146 The asymptotic Bode plot of a transfer function is as shown in the figure. The
transfer function G(s) corresponding to this Bode plot is
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+1)(s+20)}=\frac{K / 20}{s(1+s)\left(1+\frac{s}{20}\right)} [/latex] Bode plot is in (1+sT) form [latex] \begin{aligned} -20 \log \omega+20 \log K&=|60 d B|_{\omega=0.1} \\ -20 \log 0.1+20 \log K&=60 \mathrm{dB} \\ 20 \log K&=40 \mathrm{dB} \\ \Rightarrow \quad K&=100 \\ \therefore \quad G(s)&=\frac{100}{s(s+1)(1+.05 s)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 147 A unity feedback control system has an open-loop transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s^{2}+7s+12)}[/latex]
The gain K for which [latex]s=-1+j1[/latex]  will lie on the root locus of this system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T \cdot F \cdot &=\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s)} \\ A s H(s) &=1 \end{aligned} [/latex] For the point s=-1+j 1 to lie on root locus [latex] \begin{array} {l} 1+G(s)=0 \\ \Rightarrow 1+\frac{K}{s\left(s^{2}+7 s+12\right)}=0 \\ \text{Putting }\left.s^{2}+7 s+12\right)+K=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad(-1+j)(1-2 j-1-7+7 j+12)+K=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad K=+10 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 149 The transfer function of a plant is [latex]T(s)=\frac{5}{(s+5)(s^{2}+s+1)}[/latex] The second-order approximation of T(s)  using dominant pole concept is
solution: In dominant pole concept, the factor that has to be eliminated should be in time constant form. [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{5}{(s+5)\left(s^{2}+s+1\right)}=& \frac{5}{5\left(1+\frac{s}{5}\right)\left(s^{2}+s+1\right)} \\ =& \frac{1}{s^{2}+s+1} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 150 A control system with PD controller is shown in the figure. If the velocity error
constant [latex]K_{V}[/latex]=1000 and the damping ratio [latex]\varsigma[/latex]=0.5, then the value of [latex]K_{P}[/latex] and [latex]K_{D}[/latex] are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} K_{v} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s G(s) H(s) \\ 1000 &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s \times \frac{\left(K_{P}+K_{D} s\right) 100}{s(s+10)} \\ \Rightarrow \quad K_{P} &=100 \end{aligned}[/latex] Now characteristics eq. [latex](1+G(s) H(s))=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} 1+\frac{\left(K_{P}+K_{D}\right) 100}{s(s+10)}&=0 \\ \text { Putting } \quad K_{P}&=100 \\ s^{2}+10 s+10^{4}+100 K_{0} s&=0 \\ s^{2}+\left(10+100 K_{0}\right) s+10^{4}&=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Comparing with standard second order eq. [latex] \begin{array}{l} \text{i.e.}\quad s^{2}+2 \xi \omega_{n} s+\omega_{n}^{2}=0\\ \text{So,} \quad \omega_{n}=100 ; 2 \xi \omega_{n}=10+100 K_{0} \\ \text{Given,}\quad \xi=0.5 \\ 2 \times 0.5 \times 100=10+100 K_{0} \\ K_{D}=0.9 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 151 The frequency response of a linear, time-invariant system is given by [latex]H(f)=\frac{5}{1+j10 \pi f}[/latex]. The step response of the system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H(f) &=\frac{5}{1+j 10 \pi f} \\ H(s) &=\frac{5}{1+5 s} \\ &=\frac{5}{5\left(s+\frac{1}{5}\right)}=\frac{1}{s+\frac{1}{5}} \\ \text { Step response } &=\frac{1}{S} \frac{1}{\left(s+\frac{1}{5}\right)} \\ \frac{1}{s} \times \frac{1}{\left(s+\frac{1}{5}\right)} &=\frac{A}{s}+\frac{B}{s+\frac{1}{5}} \\ \Rightarrow A\left(s+\frac{1}{5}\right)&+B s=1 \end{aligned}[/latex] when [latex]s=0, A=5 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{when }\quad s&=\frac{-1}{5}, B=-5 \\ Y(s) &=\frac{5}{s}-\frac{5}{s+\frac{1}{5}} \\ \Rightarrow y(t)&=5\left[1-e^{-t / 5}\right] u(t) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 152 If the closed-loop transfer function of a control system is given as [latex]T(s)=\frac{s-5}{(s+2)(s+3)}[/latex], then it is
solution: As there is a right half zero, the system is a non-minimum phase system.

question: Question 153 Consider a unity-gain feedback control system whose open-loop transfer function is: [latex]G(s)=\frac{as+1}{s^{2}}[/latex] With the value of "a" set for a phase - margin of [latex]\frac{\pi }{4}[/latex], the value of unit-impulse response of the open-loop system at t=1 second is equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G(s)&=\frac{0.84 s+1}{s^{2}}\\ H(s) &=1, R(s)=1 \\ c(s) &=G(s) \cdot R(s) \\ \therefore \quad C(s) &=\frac{0.84 s+1}{s^{2}} \\ c(t) &=L^{-1}\left[\frac{1+0.84 s}{s^{2}}\right] \\ &=L^{-1}\left[\frac{1}{s^{2}}+\frac{0.84}{s}\right] \\ c(t) &=[t+0.84] U(t) \\ \text{At}\quad t &=1, c(t)=1+0.84=1.84 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 154 Consider a unity-gain feedback control system whose open-loop transfer function is: [latex]G(s)=\frac{as+1}{s^{2}}[/latex] The value of "a" so that the system has a phase-margin equal to [latex]\frac{\pi }{4}[/latex] is approximately equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{PM}&=\frac{\pi}{4} \\ \Rightarrow 180+\tan ^{-1} a \omega-180^{\circ}&=\frac{\pi}{4} \\ \tan \frac{\pi}{4}&=\mathrm{a} \omega \\ \Rightarrow\quad a \omega&=1 \end{aligned} [/latex] Now for gain crossover frequency, [latex] \begin{aligned} |G(s)|&=1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\sqrt{1+a^{2} \omega^{2}}}{\omega^{2}}&=1 \\ \sqrt{1+1}&=\omega^{2} \quad(\text { as } a \omega=1) \\ f^{2}&=\sqrt{2} \\ \omega&=(2)^{1 / 4} \\ a&=\frac{1}{2^{1 / 4}}=0.84 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 155 A linear system is described by the following state equation [latex]\dot{X}(t)=AX(t)+BU(t),A=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1\\ -1&0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The state transition matrix of the system is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \phi(t)=L^{-1}[S I-A]^{-1} \\ =L^{-1}\left[\left[\begin{array}{ll} s & 0 \\ 0 & s \end{array}\right]-\left[\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \end{array}\right]\right]^{-1}=L^{-1}\left[\begin{array}{cc} s & -1 \\ 1 & s \end{array}\right]^{-1} \\ =L^{-1}\left[\begin{array}{cc} \frac{s}{s^{2}+1} & \frac{1}{s^{2}+1} \\ \frac{-1}{s^{2}+1} & \frac{s}{s^{2}+1} \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} D=s^{2}+1 \\ \end{array}\right] \\ =\left[\begin{array}{cc} \cos t & \sin t \\ -\sin t & \cos t \end{array}\right] \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 156 The transfer function of a phase lead compensator is given by [latex]G_{c}(s)=\frac{1+3Ts}{1+Ts}[/latex] where [latex]T \gt 0 [/latex] The maximum phase shift provide by such a compensator is
solution:
Maximum phase shift [latex] \begin{aligned} \phi_{m} &=\angle G_{\theta}(s) \\ \phi &=\tan ^{-1} 3 \omega T-\tan ^{-1} \omega T \end{aligned}[/latex] For maximum phase shift [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{d \phi}{d \omega} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \frac{3 T}{1+(3 T \omega)^{2}} &=\frac{T}{1+(T \omega)^{2}} \\ 3\left[1+(T \omega)^{2}\right] &=1+(3 T \omega)^{2} \\ 3+3 T^{2} \omega^{2} &=1+9 T^{2} \omega^{2} \\ 2 &=6(\omega T)^{2} \\ (\omega T)^{2} &=\frac{1}{3} \\ \omega T=& \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\\phi_{\max } &=\tan ^{-1} 3 \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}-\tan ^{-1} \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\
&=\frac{\pi}{3}-\frac{\pi}{6}=\frac{\pi}{6}\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 157 The unit impulse response of a system is [latex]h(t) =  e^{-t},t\geq 0[/latex]. For this system the steady-state value of the output for unit step input is equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} h(t) &=e^{-t} \\ H(s) &=\frac{1}{s+1} \\ R(s) &=\frac{1}{s} \\ \text { Output } &=H(s) \cdot R(s)=\frac{1}{(s+1)} \cdot \frac{1}{s} \\ \frac{1}{s(s+1)} &=\frac{A}{s}+\frac{B}{s+1} \\ 1 &=A(s+1)+B s \\ s &=0,1=A \\ s &=-1,1=-B \\ \therefore \quad \text{ Output }&=\frac{1}{s}-\frac{1}{s+1} \\ & =\left(1-e^{-t}\right) u(t) \end{aligned} [/latex] When [latex]t=\infty[/latex] at steady state. Output = 1

question:
Question 158 The positive values of "K" and "a"  so that the system shown in the figures below
oscillates at a frequency of 2 rad/sec respectively are
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { 1+ } G(s) H(s)=1+\frac{K(s+1)}{s^{3}+a s^{2}+2 s+1}=0 \\ \Rightarrow \frac{s^{3}+a s^{2}+2 s+1+K s+K}{s^{3}+a s^{2}+2 s+1}=0 \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{c|cc} s^{3}& 1 &2+K\\ s^{2}&a & K+1\\ s&\frac{a(2+K)-(K+1)}{a} \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \text { For oscillation, } \frac{a(2+K)-(K+1)}{a}=0 \\ \qquad \begin{array}{l} a=\frac{K+1}{K+2} \\ a s^{2}+K+1=0 \\ s=j \omega, s^{2}=-\omega^{2}=-4 \\ \Rightarrow-4 a+K+1=0 \\ a=\frac{K+1}{4} \Rightarrow \frac{K+1}{4}=\frac{K+1}{K+2} \Rightarrow K=2 \\ a=0.75 \end{array} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 160 The unit step response of a system starting from rest is given by [latex]c(t)=1-e^{-2t} \; for \;  t\geq 0[/latex] The transfer function of the system is

question:
Question 161 In the system shown below, x(t) = (sint)u(t). In steady-state, the response y(t)
will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y(t) &=x(t) * h(t) \\ Y(s) &=X(s) \cdot H(s) \\ H(j \omega) &=\frac{1}{s+1}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \angle-45^{\circ} \\ &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \angle-\frac{\pi}{4} \\ x(t) &=\sin (t) u(t) \\ \therefore \quad y(t) &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \left(t-\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

M &=2010 g \frac{1}{a} \\ \Rightarrow 20 \log \frac{1}{2.26} &=-7.09 \end{aligned} [/latex] since, G.M. is negative system is unstable. [latex] \therefore [/latex] P.M. is also negative. question: Question 164 The open loop transfer function of a unity feedback is given by [latex]G(s)=\frac{3e^{-2s}}{s(s+2)}[/latex]. The gain and phase crossover frequencies in rad/sec are, respectively
solution: Gain cross over frequency where gain is 1. [latex] \begin{aligned} |G(s)| &=1 \\ \Rightarrow \frac{3}{\omega\left(\omega^{2}+4\right)^{12}} &=1 \\ \Rightarrow \frac{9}{\omega^{2}\left(\omega^{2}+4\right)} &=1 \\ \Rightarrow \omega_{g}&=1.26 \end{aligned}[/latex] Phase cross over frequency [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Where }\angle G H&=-180^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \omega_{p c}&=0.632\left(\frac{\omega_{\phi}}{2}=\cot 2 \omega_{\phi}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 165 An unity feedback system is given as [latex]G(s)=\frac{K(1-s)}{s(s+3)}[/latex] Indicate the correct root locus diagram.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} 1+G(s) H(s) &=0 \\ K &=\frac{s^{2}+3 s}{1-s} \end{aligned}[/latex] For break away and break in point [latex] \begin{array}{l} \quad \frac{d K}{d s}=(1-s)(2 s+3)+s^{2}+3 s=0 \\ =-s^{2}+2 s+3=0 \\ \Rightarrow s^{2}-2 s-3=0 \\ \Rightarrow(s-3)(s+1)=0 \\ s=3,-1 \end{array}[/latex] -1 is the breakaway point and 3 is the break in point.

question:

achieve the damping ratio [latex]\zeta[/latex]=0.5, and an undamped natural frequency, [latex]\omega _{n}[/latex]=5 rad/sec.  Which one of the following compensator [latex]G_{c}(s)[/latex] will be suitable ?
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned} & \xi=0.5 \\ \cos ^{-1} 0.5 &=60^{\circ} \\ \therefore \quad \theta &=60^{\circ}\\ \angle G(s) &=\left.\frac{K}{s^{2}}\right|_{s=-2.5+4.33 j} \\ &=-2 \tan ^{-1} \frac{4.33}{-2.5} ; 120^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] For compensated system 
 [latex]\angle=180-120; \; 60^{\circ} [/latex] (b) & (d) are lag network & for compensating lag network  [latex]K /s^{2}[/latex], a lead network is required [latex] \therefore [/latex] Putting [latex]s=-2.5+4.33 j [/latex] in (a) gives [latex] \frac{K(s+3)}{s^{2}(s+9.9)}=\frac{0.5+j 4.33}{7.4+j 4.33}=53^{\circ} ; 60^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Option (A) is the correct answer.

question:
Question 167 A ramp input applied to an unity feedback system results in 5% steady state
error. The type number and zero frequency gain of the system are respectively
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} e_{s s} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s E(s), R(s)=\frac{1}{s^{2}} \\ &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s \frac{R(s)}{1+G(s)} \\ &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{s+s G(s)}=\text { finite (given) } \\ K_{v} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s G(s) \\ e_{s s} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{s G(s)}=\text { finite }=5 \%=\frac{1}{20} \\ \therefore \quad K &=20 \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] K_{v}[/latex] is finite for type 1 system having ramp input.

question: Question 172 A linear system is equivalently represented by two sets of state equations : [latex]\dot{X}=AX+BU \; and \;  W=CW+DU[/latex] The eigenvalues of the representations are also computed as [latex][\lambda][/latex] and [latex][\mu][/latex]. Which one of the following statements is true ?
solution:
Eigen vlues of [latex]A=[\lambda][/latex] Eigen values of  [latex]W=[\mu] [/latex] The eigen values of a system are always unique. [latex]
 \mathrm{So},[\lambda]=[\mu] [/latex] But a system can be represented by different state 
models having different set of state variables. [latex]
\begin{array}{l}
X=W \\
X \neq W
\end{array}[/latex] Both are possible conditions.

question: Question 173 Given [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 0&1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex], the state transition matrix [latex]e^{At}[/latex] is given by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} [s I-A] &=\left[\begin{array}{ll}s & 0 \\0 & s\end{array}\right]-\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 0 \\0 & 1\end{array}\right] \\ s I-A] & =\left[\begin{array}{cc}s-1 & 0 \\0 & s-1\end{array}\right] \\ e^{A t} & =[s I-A]^{-1}\\ &=\left[\begin{array}{cc}-\frac{1}{s-1} & 0 \\ 0 & \frac{1}{s-1}\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{ll}e^{t} & 0 \\ 0 & e^{t}\end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 174 The state variable equations of a system are : 1.  [latex]\dot{x_{1}}=-3x_{1}-x_{2}+u[/latex] 2. [latex]\dot{x_{2}}=2x_{1}[/latex] [latex]y=x_{1}+u[/latex] The system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{c}\dot{x}_{1} \\\dot{x}_{2}\end{array}\right]&=\left[\begin{array}{cc}-3 & -1 \\2 & 0\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}x_{1} \\x_{2}\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\0\end{array}\right] u \\ y&=\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 0\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}x_{1} \\x_{2}\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\0\end{array}\right] u \\ Q_{C}&=\left[\begin{array}{ll}B & A B\end{array}\right]\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} A B&=\left[\begin{array}{c}-3 \\ 2\end{array}\right] \\ \therefore \quad a_{c}&=\left[\begin{array}{cc}1 & -3 \\ 0 & 2\end{array}\right] \neq 0 \\ \therefore \text{Controllable } \\ Q_{0}&=\left[C^{\top} \quad A^{\top} C^{\prime}\right] \\ C^{T}&=\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right], \quad A^{T}&=\left[\begin{array}{ll}-3 & 2 \\ -1 & 0\end{array}\right] \\ A^{\top} C^{T}&=\left[\begin{array}{l}-3 \\ -1\end{array}\right] \\ \therefore \quad Q_{0}&=\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & -3 \\ 0 & -1\end{array}\right] \neq 0 \\ \therefore \text{ Observable} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 175 For the polynomial [latex]P(s)=s^{5}+s^{4}+2s^{3}+2s^{2}+3s+15[/latex], the number of roots
which lie in the right half of the s -plane is
solution: [latex]P(s)=s^{5}+s^{4}+2 s^{3}+2 s^{2}+3 s+15 [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{c|ccc} s^{5}& 1 & 2 & 3 \\ s^{4} & 1 & 2 & 15 \\ s^{3} & 0(\epsilon) & -12 & 0 \\ s^{2} & \frac{2 \epsilon+12}{\epsilon} & 15 & 0 \\ s&\frac{\frac{\frac{-12(2 \epsilon+12)}{\epsilon}}{\epsilon }-15 \epsilon }{\frac{\epsilon}{\left(\frac{2 \epsilon+12}{\epsilon}\right)}}&& \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \frac{2 \epsilon+12}{\epsilon}=t [/latex] Let [latex]\in[/latex] be a small positive no. [latex] \frac{-12 t-15 \epsilon}{t} [/latex] [latex] s \Rightarrow-12-\frac{15 \epsilon}{t} [/latex] [latex] s ^{0}\quad 15[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Two sign change from [latex]s^{2}[/latex] to s and s to [latex]s^{0} [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] 2 roots on RHS of s plane.

question: Question 176 The open-loop transfer function of a unity feedback system is [latex]G(s)=\frac{K}{s(s^{2}+s+2)(s+3)}[/latex]. The range of K for which the system is stable is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} G(s)=\frac{K}{s\left(s^{2}+s+2\right)(s+3)} \\ H(s)=1\\ 1+G(s) H(s)=1+\frac{K}{s\left(s^{3}+3 s^{2}+s^{2}+3 s+2 s+6\right)} \\ =\frac{s^{4}+4 s^{3}+5 s^{2}+6 s+K}{s\left(s^{3}+4 s^{2}+5 s+6\right)} \\ 1+G(s) H(s)=0 \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l|ll}s^{4} & 1 & 5\;K \\ s^{3} & 4 & 6 \\ s^{2} & \frac{7}{2} & k \\ s & \frac{\frac{7}{2} \times 6-4 K}{\frac{7}{2}} & 0 \\ s^{0} & k & \frac{7}{2}\end{array} [/latex] For system to be stable, [latex]K \gt 0[/latex] [latex] (21-4 K) \cdot \frac{2}{7}\gt 0 [/latex] [latex] \frac{21}{4} \gt K \Rightarrow K\lt \frac{21}{4} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \frac{21}{4} \gt K \gt 0[/latex]

question: Question 177 Consider the signal flow graph shown in Fig. The gain [latex]\frac{X_{5}}{X_{1}}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} P_{1}=a b c d, \quad \Delta_{1}=1 \\ L_{1}=b e, L_{2}=c f, L_{3}=d g \\ \text { Non-touching loops are } L_{1} \& L_{3}=b e d g \\ \therefore \quad \frac{X_{5}}{X_{1}}=\frac{a b c d}{1-(b e+c f+d g)+b e d g} \end{array}[/latex]

Pole at 0.01 and 1 Hz gives [latex]-180^{\circ}[/latex] phase. Zero at 5 Hz gives [latex]+90^{\circ}[/latex] phase [latex]

question:
Question 179 A causal system having the transfer function H(s)=1/(s+2) is excited with
10u(t). The time at which the output reaches 99% of its steady state value is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H(s) &=\frac{1}{s+2} \\ r(t) &=10 u(t) \\ R(s) &=\frac{10}{s} \\ C(s) &=H(s) \cdot R(s)=\frac{1}{s+2} \cdot \frac{10}{s} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{10}{s(s+2)} &=\frac{A}{s}+\frac{B}{s+2} \\ 10 &=A(s+2)+B s \\ s &=0,10=2 A \\ \Rightarrow \quad A &=5 \\ s &=-2,10=-2 B \\ \Rightarrow \quad B &=-5 \\ \therefore \quad C(s) &=\frac{5}{s}-\frac{5}{s+2} \\ c(t) &=5\left[1-e^{2 t}\right] u(t) \end{aligned}[/latex] Steady state value when t=0 is 5.99% of steady state value reaches at [latex] \begin{aligned} & 5\left[1-e^{2 t}\right]=0.99 \times 5 \\ \Rightarrow \quad & 1-e^{-2 t}=0.99 \\ & e^{2 t}=0.1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad &-2 t=\ln 0.1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad & t=2.3 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 180 A system described by the following differential equation [latex]\frac{d^{2}y}{dt^{2}}+3\frac{dy}{dt}+2y=x(t)[/latex] is initially at rest. For input x(t)=2u(t), the output y(t) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{d^{2} y}{d t^{2}}+\frac{3 d y}{d t}+2 y &=X(t) \\ s^{2} Y(s)+3 s Y(s)+2 Y(s) &=X(s) \\ x(t) &=2 u(t) \\ X(s) &=\frac{2}{s} \\ \therefore \quad\left(s^{2}+3 s+2\right) Y(s) &=\frac{2}{s} \\ r(s) &=\frac{2}{s(s+2)(s+1)} \\ \frac{2}{s(s+2)(s+1)} &=\frac{A}{s}+\frac{B}{s+2}+\frac{C}{s+1} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} 2&=A(s+2)(s+1)+B s(s+1)+C(s+2) s \\ s&=0,2=2 A \Rightarrow A=1 \\ s&=-1,2=-C \Rightarrow C=-2 \\ s&=-2,2=2 B \Rightarrow B=1 \\ Y(s)&=\frac{1}{s}+\frac{1}{s+2}-\frac{2}{s+1} \\ y(t)&=(1+e^{-2 t}-2 e^{-t}) u(t)  \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 181 Consider the Bode magnitude plot shown in the fig. The transfer function H(s) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} 20 \log K &=-20 \mathrm{dB} \\ \Rightarrow \quad K &=10^{-1}=0.1 \\ \text { Zero at } \omega=1 & \& \text { poles at } \omega=10,100 \\ H(s) &=\frac{K(s+1)}{\left(\frac{s}{10}+1\right)\left(\frac{s}{100}+1\right)} \\ &=\frac{0.1(s+1) \times 10 \times 100}{(s+10)(s+100)} \\ &=\frac{10^2 (s+1)}{(s+10)(s+100)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 182 Given [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+1)(s+3)}[/latex],  the point of intersection of the asymptotes of
the root loci with the real axis is
solution: [latex]\text { Centroid }=\frac{\Sigma P-\Sigma Z}{P-Z}=\frac{-1-3}{3}=-1.33[/latex]

question: Question 183 The gain margin for the system with open-loop transfer function [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{2(1+s)}{s^{2}}[/latex], is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \angle G(s) H(s) &=-180^{\circ}+\tan ^{-1} \omega \\ \text{For}\quad\omega_{\theta} &=-180^{\circ}+\tan ^{-1} \omega=-180^{\circ} \\ \omega &=0 \\ |G(s) H(s)| &=\frac{2 \sqrt{1+\omega^{2}}}{\omega^{2}}=\infty \\ G \cdot M \cdot &=\frac{1}{\infty}=0 \\ \ln \quad d B G \cdot M &=\infty \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 184 The zero-input response of a system given by the state-space equation [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \dot{X_1}\\\dot{X_2} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \\ 1& 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} X_1\\X_2 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] and [latex]\begin{bmatrix} X_1(0)\\X_2(0) \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} (s I-A) &=\left[\begin{array}{ll} s & 0 \\ 0 & s \end{array}\right]-\left[\begin{array}{ll} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{array}\right] \\ &=\left[\begin{array}{cc} s-1 & 0 \\ -1 & s-1 \end{array}\right] \\ (s I-A)^{-1} &=\frac{\left[\begin{array}{cc} (s-1) & 0 \\ +1 & (s-1) \end{array}\right]}{(s-1)^{2}}\\ &=\left[\begin{array}{cc}\frac{1}{s-1} & 0 \\ \frac{+1}{(s-1)^{2}} & \frac{1}{s-1}\end{array}\right] \\ L^{-1}[s I-A]^{-1}&=e^{A t}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}e^{t} & 0 \\ t e^{t} & e^{t}\end{array}\right] \\ &=\left[\begin{array}{cc}e^{t} & 0 \\ t e^{t} & e^{t}\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c}e^{t} \\ t e^{t}\end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 185 The gain margin and the phase margin of feedback system with [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{s}{(s+100)^{3}}[/latex] are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G(s) H(s)&=\frac{s}{(s+100)^{3}}\\ \text{Calculating } \omega_{\mathrm{pc}}, \\ -180^{\circ}&=+90-3 \tan ^{-1} \frac{\omega_{p c}}{100} \\ -270^{\circ}&=-3 \tan ^{-1} \frac{\omega_{p c}}{100}\\ \text{or, }\quad\omega_{p c}&=\infty\\ \therefore \quad\mathrm{G} \cdot \mathrm{M} \cdot&=\infty \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence cannot be determined. Calculating [latex]\omega_{g c} [/latex] [latex] \text { From, }|G(s) H(s)|=1[/latex] [latex] \omega_{g c}=[/latex] negative value G.M. and P.M. of the system cannot be determined.

question: Question 186 A second-order system has the transfer function [latex]\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{4}{s^{2}+4s+4}[/latex]. With r(t) as the unit-step function, the response c(t) of the system is represented by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{C(s)}{R(s)} &=\frac{4}{s^{2}+4 s+4} \\ 2 \xi(0) &=4, \omega_{n}=2 \\ \therefore \quad \xi &=1 \quad \text { (Critical damping) } \\ t_{s} &=\frac{4}{\xi \omega_{n}}=\frac{4}{1 \times 2}=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

[latex] \therefore [/latex] one pole at [latex] \omega=100 [/latex] [latex] \therefore T(s)=\frac{K(s+0.1)^{3}}{(s+10)^{2}(s+100)} [/latex] [latex] \left.20 \log (K / \omega)\right|_{\omega=10}=140 [/latex] [latex] \left.\frac{K}{\omega}\right|_{\omega=10}=10^{7} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad K=10^{8}[/latex]

question:
Question 188 The root locus of system [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{K}{s(s+2)(s+3)}[/latex] has the break-away point
located at
solution:
[latex]\begin{array}{l} 1+G(s) H(s)=0 \\ \Rightarrow 1+\frac{K}{s(s+2)(s+3)}=0 \\ \Rightarrow 1+\frac{K}{s\left(s^{2}+5 s+6\right)}=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad K=-1 \cdot\left(s^{3}+5 s^{2}+6 s\right) \\ \Rightarrow \frac{d K}{d s}=-\left(3 s^{2}+10 s+6\right) \\ \text{For break away point  } \frac{d K}{d s}=0 \\ \Rightarrow 3 s^{2}+10 s+6=0 \\ s=\frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{100-72}}{6} \\ =\frac{-10 \pm 5.3}{6}=-0.784,-2.55 \\ \end{array}[/latex] Centroid  [latex]=\frac{-2-3}{3}=\frac{-5}{3}=-1.66 [/latex] angle of asymtotes  [latex]=(2 K+1) \frac{\pi}{P-Z}   [/latex] [latex]
=(2 K+1) \frac{\pi}{3} [/latex] [latex]
 \frac{\pi}{3}, \pi, \frac{5 \pi}{3} [/latex] [latex]
 \therefore  [/latex] Break away point is (-0.784,0) 
as -2.55 does not lie on RL.

question: Question 189 The signal flow graph of a system is shown in Fig. below. The transfer function C(s)/R(s) of the system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{1}&=1 \\ \Delta_{1}&=1+\frac{3}{s}+\frac{24}{s}=\frac{s+27}{s}\\ G(s) &=\frac{P_{1} \Delta_{1}}{1-(\text { loop gain })+\text { pair of non- touching loops }} \\ L_{1}&=\frac{-3}{s}, L_{2} =\frac{-24}{s}, L_{3}=\frac{-2}{s} \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] L_{1}[/latex] and [latex]L_{3}[/latex] are non-touching. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore G(s)&=\frac{\frac{(s+27)}{s}}{1-\left(\frac{-3}{s}-\frac{24}{s}-\frac{2}{s}\right)+\frac{-2}{s} \times \frac{-3}{s}} \\ &=\frac{\frac{(s+27)}{s}}{1+\frac{29}{s}+\frac{6}{s^{2}}} \\ \frac{C(s)}{R(s)} &=\frac{s(s+27)}{s^{2}+29 s+6} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 192 The system with the open loop transfer function [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{1}{s(s^{2}+s+1)}[/latex] has a gain margin of
solution: [latex]G(s) H(s)=\frac{1}{s\left(s^{2}+s+1\right)}[/latex] [latex] \omega [/latex] when [latex] \angle G(s) H(s)=-180^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} -180 &=-90-\tan ^{-1} \frac{\omega}{1-\omega^{2}} \\ -90 &=-\tan ^{-1} \frac{\omega}{1-\omega^{2}} \\ 1-\omega^{2} &=0 \\ \omega_{\alpha c} &=1 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex] Value of gain at [latex]\omega_{\rho c}=1 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} |G(s) H(s)| &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\left(\left(1-\omega^{2}\right)^{2}+|j \omega|^{2}\right.}} \\ \therefore \quad G \cdot M \cdot &=-20 \log 1=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 193 The characteristic polynomial of a system is [latex]q (s) = 2s^{5}+s^{4}+4s^{3}+2s^{2}+2s+1[/latex]. The system is
solution: Routh table is [latex] \begin{array}{c|ccc} s^{5} & 2(1) & 4(2) & 2(1) \\ s^{4} & 1 & 2 & 1 \\ s^{3} & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ s^{2} & & & \\ s^{1} & & & \\ s^{0} & & & \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \frac{d}{d s}\left(s^{4}+2 s^{2}+1\right) &=0 \\ 4 s^{3}+4 s &=0 \\ s &=\pm j, s=\pm j \\ \frac{d}{d s}\left(s^{2}+1\right) &=0 \\ 2 s &=0 \\ \Rightarrow s &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Double roots on imaginary axis so system is unstable

question: Question 194 The transfer function of a system is [latex]G(s)=\frac{100}{(s+1)(s+100)}[/latex]. For a unit step input to the system the approximate settling time for 2% criterion is
solution: [latex]G(s)=\frac{100}{(s+1)(s+100)}[/latex] Taking dominant pole consideration, [latex] s=-100[/latex] pole is not taken. [latex] \therefore \quad G(s)=\frac{100}{s+1} [/latex] Now it is 1 st order system [latex] \therefore \quad t_{s}=4 T=4 \times 1=4 \mathrm{s}[/latex]

question: Question 195 The system shown in figure remains stable when
solution: [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{\frac{K}{s}}{1-\left(\frac{3}{s}+\frac{K}{s}\right)}=\frac{K}{s-(3+K)} [/latex] For system to be stable, [latex] \begin{aligned} 3+K& \lt 0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad K& \lt -3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 196 The transfer function Y(s)U(s) of a system described by the state equations
x(t) = -2x(t) + 2u(t) and y(t) = 0.5x(t) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \dot{x}(t)=-2 x(t)+2 u(t) &\ldots(i)\\ y(t)=0.5 x(t)&\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] From (i), Taking Laplace transform of (i) [latex] \begin{aligned} s X(s)&=-2 X(s)+2 U(s)\\ X(s)[s+2]&=2 U(s)\\ \Rightarrow \quad X(s)&=\frac{2 U(s)}{(s+2)} \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking Laplace transform of (ii) [latex] \begin{aligned} Y(s)&=0.5 X(s) \\ Y(s)&=\frac{0.5 \times 2 U(s)}{s+2} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{Y(s)}{U(s)}&=\frac{1}{(s+2)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 197 The phase margin of a system with the open-loop transfer function [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{(1-s)}{(s+1)(s+2)}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{PM}&=180^{\circ}+\left.\angle \mathrm{GH}(j \omega)\right|_{\omega_{9 c}} \\ \text { For } \omega_{\mathrm{gc}^{\prime}} &|G(s) H(s)|_{\omega=\omega_{\infty}}=1\\ \left|\frac{1-s}{(1+s)(2+s)}\right|&=\frac{\sqrt{1+\omega^{2}}}{\sqrt{1+\omega^{2} \sqrt{4+\omega^{2}}}}&=1 \\ \sqrt{4+\omega^{2}}&=1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 4+\omega^{2}&=1 \\ \omega^{2}&=-3 \text{ (imaginary)}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] So no gain crossover frequency [latex] \therefore PM=\infty[/latex]

question: Question 199 Consider a system with the transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{s+6}{ks^{2}+s+6}[/latex]. Its damping ratio will be 0.5 when the value of k is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \frac{s+6}{k\left(s^{2}+\frac{s}{k}+\frac{6}{k}\right)} \\ \text { Comparing with } s^{2}+2 \xi \omega_{n}+\omega_{n}^{2} \\ \begin{aligned} \omega_{n}&=\sqrt{\frac{6}{k}} \\ 2 \xi \omega_{n}&=\frac{1}{k} \\ 2 \times 0.5 \times \sqrt{\frac{6}{k}}&=\frac{1}{k} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \frac{6}{k}&=\frac{1}{k^{2}} \\ k&=\frac{1}{6} \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 200 The feedback control system in figure is stable
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T . F . &=\frac{G_{1} G_{2}}{1+G_{1} G_{2} H} \\ &=\frac{\frac{K(s-2)}{(s+2)^{2}}}{1+\frac{K(s-2)(s-2)}{(s+2)^{2}}} \\ &=\frac{K(s-2)}{(s+2)^{2}+K(s-2)^{2}} \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Characteristic equation [latex] =s^{2}+4+4 s+K s^{2}-4 K s+4 K [/latex] [latex] (1+K) s^{2}+K(4-4 K) s+4 K+4=0 [/latex] Routh table is [latex] \begin{array}{l|ll} s^{2} & (1+K) & (4 K+4) \\ s^{1} & K(4-4 K) & 0 \\ s^{0} & 4(K+1) & \end{array}[/latex] For system to be stable, [latex] \begin{aligned} 1-K& \gt 0\\ 1& \gt K \text{ and } K \geq 0 \quad \text{ (given in question)} \end{aligned}[/latex] From third row, [latex] \begin{aligned} K& \gt -1 \\ \therefore \quad 0 &\leq K \lt 1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 201 The open-loop DC gain of a unity negative feedback system with closed-loop
transfer function [latex]\frac{s+4}{s^{2}+7s+13}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{CLTF} &=\frac{G(s)}{1+G(s) H(s)}=\frac{s+4}{s^{2}+7 s+13} \\ \frac{1+G(s) H(s)}{G(s)} &=\frac{s^{2}+7 s+13}{s+4} \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] H(s)=1[/latex] for unity feedback. [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{G(s)} &=\frac{s^{2}+7 s+13}{s+4}-1 \\ \frac{1}{G(s)} &=\frac{s^{2}+6 s+9}{s+4} \\ \therefore \quad G(s) &=\frac{s+4}{s^{2}+6 s+9} \\ \text { For D.C. } \quad s&=0\\ \therefore \quad G(s) &=\text{open loop gain} \\ &=\frac{4}{9} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 202 An electrical system and its signal-flow graph representations are shown in figure
 (a) and (b) respectively. The values of [latex]G_{2}[/latex] and H, respectively are
solution: From KVL in both loops In first loop, [latex] V_{i}(s)=I_{1}(s) Z_{1}(s)+\left[I_{1}(s)-I_{2}(s)\right] Z_{3}(s) [/latex] [latex] V_{i}(s)=I_{1}(s)\left[Z_{1}(s)+Z_{3}(s)\right]-I_{2}(s) Z_{3}(s) [/latex] [latex] \frac{V_{i}(s)}{Z_{1}(s)+Z_{3}(s)}=I_{1}(s)-\frac{I_{2}(s) \cdot Z_{3}(s)}{Z_{1}(s)+Z_{3}(s)} \; \; ...(i)[/latex] In second loop, [latex] \left[I_{2}(s)-I_{1}(s)\right] Z_{3}(s)+I_{2}(s) Z_{2}(s)+I_{2}(s) Z_{4}(s)=0 [/latex] [latex] I_{2}(s)\left(Z_{2}(s)+Z_{3}(s)+Z_{4}(s)\right)=I_{1}(s) \cdot Z_{3}(s) [/latex] [latex] G_{2}=\frac{I_{2}(s)}{I_{1}(s)}=\frac{Z_{3}(s)}{Z_{2}(s)+Z_{3}(s)+Z_{4}(s)} [/latex] From SFG, [latex]I_{1}(s)=V_{i} G_{1}(s)+I_{2}(s) H(s) [/latex] [latex] I_{1}(s)=V_{i}(s) \frac{1}{Z_{1}(s)+Z_{3}(s)}+I_{2}(s) \frac{Z_{3}(s)}{Z_{1}(s)+Z_{3}(s)} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad H(s)=\frac{Z_{3}(s)}{Z_{1}(s)+Z_{3}(s)} [/latex] (comparing above two equations)

question:

feedback system is shown in figure. If G(s) has no pole in the right half of splane, the number of roots of the system characteristic equation in the right half
of s-plane is
solution: [latex]N=0[/latex] (1 encirclement in CW direction and other in ACW) [latex] P=0 [/latex](no pole in right half) So, [latex]N=P-Z[/latex] [latex] Z=P-N=0[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad [/latex] No roots on RH of s-plane.

question: Question 204 The root-locus diagram for a closed loop feedback system is shown in figure. The system is overdamped.
solution:
For overdamping roots of characteristic equation 
should lie on negative axis and be unequal.

question: Question 205 If the characteristic equation of a closed-loop system is [latex]s^{2}+2s+2=0[/latex], then the system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} s^{2}+2 \xi \omega_{n}+\omega_{n}^{2} &=0 \\ 2 \xi\omega{n} &=2, \xi=\frac{1}{\omega_{n}} \\ \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{2}\\ \therefore \quad \xi&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \because \xi \lt 1,[/latex] hence response will be underdamped.
